The government provides matching funding for research and development expenditure on a dollar for dollar basis.
It is worthwhile noting that to date levy rates have been set and altered at the request of industry. I do not anticipate that this will change.

At present, the legislation specifies a complex range of levy rates for the marketing component. This makes for an unwieldy process when changing the levy rates for the marketing component. The bill instead provides that the levy rates will be set out in regulations, as is the usual case for horticultural levies. This will facilitate execution of industry requests to change the levy and bring it into line with normal practice. At the same time a maximum amount—0.5 per cent of the gross value of production—is set for the marketing component.

The act already provides that the levy rates for the research component be specified by regulation. The research levy rate is at present $1.90 per tonne and the legislation sets a limit of $2 per tonne for this levy. The maximum was set in the original act of 1979 and needs to be raised to $3 per tonne to enable the industry to increase its funding of industry research and development, if it so desires.

The bill also ends the exemption that smaller winemakers, those processing less than 10 tonnes of product, had from paying levy. As non-payers, those winemakers have no representation in the decisions and operations of the corporation and its regulatory functions.

It is intended that these winemakers will pay the small annual fee that constitutes the minimum levy rate, in return for which they will have the right to represent their interests at annual general meetings of the corporation and to receive the services and information that the corporation provides to its levy payers.

Honourable members will be aware that the corporation's role is of considerable importance in the Australian wine industry's drive to reach an annual export level of $1 billion by the year 2000. Many small producers will not be exporters, but the changes in the domestic market directly affect them. Such changes include the effects of expanded trade on grape supplies and Australia's commitment to end the use of European geographical indications in labelling our wine.

It is important that the small winemakers not be left out of consideration in the strategic development of the Australian wine industry. It is important that their voice be heard. Their present ineligibility to be members of the AWBC prevents them from having the opportunity. The bill is intended to redress this situation.
I commend this bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES (WINE GRAPES) COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill is to amend the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991, the `collection act', to allow small wine producers to pay levy in their own right and represent themselves at annual general meetings of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation.

Small winemakers often forward grapes to another, usually larger, winemaker who converts the material into wine under instructions for a fee, known as `toll processing'. The wine is then returned to the smaller winemaker for him or her to market. The smaller winemaker owns the wine throughout the process.

Under the current legislation, the larger winemaker is the `producer' and is liable for levy on the wine. This cost is usually added to the fee charged to the smaller winemaker. The smaller winemaker is therefore the effective, but not the official, levy payer and accordingly is not entitled to attend, debate or vote in the industry annual general meeting of the corporation.

The amendments proposed will permit small winemakers who toll process to pay levy directly and to accept the rights and obligations of levy payers. Although the legislation will allow small winemakers who have their wines toll processed to be recognised as the official levy payers, the government has put forward the related Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 to ensure that product from small winemakers is leviable product.

By redefining `producer' for the purposes of the wine grapes levy under the collection act, small winemakers will become the official levy payers in their own right and will be able to represent their own interests to the corporation.
I commend the bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY ADMINISTRATION (MEAT CHICKENS) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill provides for an increase in the maximum rate of levy under the national residue survey for meat chickens. The increase has been requested by the peak industry body, the Australian Chicken Meat Federation, in order to maintain flexibility for changes to the survey programs required for the chicken meat industry in the coming years.
I commend the bill to honourable members.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding, I will explain standing order 217C which deals with cognate debate. This morning the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) sought leave for certain bills to be declared cognate. That has been done: there are now four bills that are being considered in cognate debate. The standing order states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the Minister, in moving that the first of the bills be read a second time, and Members in speaking in the subsequent debate, may refer to the subject matter of all the bills.

So whilst there is only one motion before us, that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) be read a second time, all four bills can be referred to in debate. Subsequently, when we have dispensed with the motion for the second reading of the primary industries bill, we will then move formally the motions for the second readings of the other bills.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is being debated here today in cognate. The other three bills are the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: The four pieces of legislation cover an amazing array of primary industries. It is perhaps a timely reminder to us all that primary industry in Australia covers a most diverse and dynamic spectrum of products, people and markets. It is most heartening to observe a common theme running through these four bills. It is the strong desire within those who work in and for our primary industries to help themselves.
The coalition will be moving an amendment to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), and I will deal with it at the conclusion of my contribution to this debate.

The National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994 provides for the maximum rate of the national residue survey levy to increase from 0.02 per cent per head to 0.06 per cent per head. Almost all primary industries in Australia contribute to a national residue survey in order to ensure the food they produce is free of harmful residues. The survey for each particular industry is now fully funded by the industry itself. It is an industry helping itself by ensuring it contributes to, in this case, the national residue survey. In this case, the Chicken Meat Federation sought the increase in order to incorporate greater flexibility into the industry's long-term planning.

The coalition supports this legislation. It is perhaps timely to consider the value of the chicken meat industry. So often we consider the primary industries legislation and the impact that it has on Australia very much in the context of the big ticket items such as wheat, wool, beef and other agricultural products; often we do not give the due importance that we should to the chicken meat industry because it is a very large and expanding industry.

As I said, as an industry it receives little publicity but it has quietly transformed itself from its backyard status—most recently as late as the 1960s—to a modern, dynamic industry which places second only to beef in the meat production stakes. Some 40 years ago, Australians consumed about three million birds annually, or less than half a kilogram of chicken meat each over the course of a year. The situation is now radically different. In 1993-94, we collectively munched our way through 325 million birds. That is a surprising figure: 325 million chickens includes 650 million drumsticks which equates to a consumption level of 27.4 kilograms of chicken meat per capita.

It is quite easy from those figures to see how our diet in Australia is changing. Of course, because of the product and because of the value of chicken meat, the chicken meat industry is certainly taking a very large chunk out of the traditional meat industry's per capita consumption. They are certainly surprising figures.To put that in perspective, each Australian consumed the equivalent of two Kentucky Fried Chicken snack packs or three McChickens or perhaps 13 bowls of chicken noodle soup each week for a whole year.

Suffice to say, we Australians like our chicken. Not only do we enjoy the taste and health benefits of chicken meat; we gain substantially from the economic benefits of the industry. The chicken meat industry directly employs about 16,000 people and about 45,000 people are indirectly involved. The current value of sales at a retail level is approaching $1.7 billion.

I think it is timely to point out that because this is an intensive animal feeding industry it is going to be affected by the drought. The cost of grain in Australia has been brought about and may be a direct result of the raging drought that we have seen across the eastern states of Australia over the last four years. Grain prices for the chicken meat industry are going to rise and they have already risen. That is going to place an increasing burden on the viability of the chicken meat industry. In turn, those costs have either got to be absorbed by the industry or passed on to the consumer. If they pass directly on to the consumer, we are going to see an inflationary impact on the Australian nation.

This drought has wider ramifications than the plight of those who are directly involved who we see on a day-to-day basis in the rural electorates of Australia. It will impact on the national economy; it will impact on the CPI—the consumer price index, the cost of living in Australia. That is a direct result of the drought. That is why we do need to see from the government today a national response to this great tragedy that is out there in rural Australia. It does deserve, albeit too late for many, a national response. That national response must cover the impact that this drought is having on communities, families and industries because it is a national disaster.

There is enormous potential for export development but the industry in Australia remains hamstrung by the high cost of capital, the high cost of labour and other inputs, and the subsidies provided to the chicken meat industry in competing countries. The United States and the European Union are particularly aggressive protectors of their domestic chicken meat industries. Thailand has rapidly assumed a prominent position amongst the world's chicken meat exporters by relying on tax incentives to lure foreign investment, and cheap labour, to build a most efficient industry in that country.

The possible relaxation of Australian quarantine regulations relating to imported chicken meat is of great concern to the domestic industry. This concern is twofold. Naturally, there is concern for the impact on local producers, but just as important is the concern for the possible introduction of the world's most feared disease in the poultry industry, the Newcastle virus. I applaud the chicken meat industry for the high standards it supports and upholds—in particular, with regard to its approach to hygiene, disease eradication and quality control. I sincerely hope that the industry's commitment to development and innovation is matched by a similar level of commitment from the federal government to eliminate factors which impede the industry's growth, whilst maintaining secure quarantine restrictions. We all benefit from agricultural products in Australia which are clean and green and are the envy of many other countries in the world.

The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994 end the current levy exemption for wine producers producing less than 10 tonnes of fresh grapes, place a maximum limit on the amount of levy that is used to support marketing, and increase the limit on the research and development component. A proportion of the money raised through the wine grapes levy finances the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. This body is responsible for wine promotion, administration of the wine label integrity program, export control and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine.

The remainder funds the Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation. Funding spent on research is matched by the government on a dollar for dollar basis. I understand that both the Australian Wine Makers Forum and the Independent Winemakers, both of which represent small winemakers, support the alteration proposed by this legislation. The coalition will be supporting the legislation.

The Australian wine industry continues to be a primary industry of great success. As the reputation of our wine spreads throughout the world, our export trade continues to strengthen. In 1994-95, it is estimated we will export 162 million litres of wine. This amounts to an increase of almost 400 per cent since 1989-90. In value terms, the exports are expected to come close to $500 million.

One of the most exciting developments in the wine industry is the agreement reached between Australia and the European Community, which was negotiated late in 1992 and signed in January this year. This agreement will result in the improved access of Australian wine to European markets and eliminate technical trade barriers, in return for the phasing out of the use of European geographical names as names for Australian wine.

The search for new names to replace beaujolais, hock, madeira, chianti and, eventually, champagne, chablis, moselle and many others will be a challenge for Australian winemakers. It does, however, provide an enormous opportunity for Australian wines to further establish their particular market niche with distinctive and unique names. It will be a formidable task to educate the wine drinkers of the world to accept the new names. I do not underestimate that task, because people have for so long associated the variety of a wine with a region, and it is going to be extremely difficult and a great challenge, obviously, to the wine industry to develop new names which will be identifiable the world over.

However, for an industry which has displayed enormous marketing and product development prowess, I feel that it is a challenge to which the wine industry is certainly capable of rising. I recently noticed an Australian wine selling under the name of `Antarctic White'. That seemed to me to be an excellent example of a name which provides a clear impression of the wine's style whilst also establishing the wine's geographic origin.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't come from your electorate!

—I am getting to my electorate very shortly. This agreement is a great example of the wine industry's foresight and vision. I have no doubt that the industry will achieve its $1 billion annual exports target set for the year 2000. It is a wonderful example to us all to see that an industry out there has a target which it wants to achieve; it has a plan. We can only wish the wine industry well, and let us hope that it does reach that target before the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that we consider the impact the drought is having on our Australian wine industry. In my electorate, in the granite belt, we have got an emerging wine industry. It has been there for a long time, but it is expanding. One of the limiting factors to the expansion of that wine industry is water. It is time that this nation looked more seriously at a national water strategy. We so often find that our agricultural potential is limited by the impact of drought. Whilst we look at the social issues, I do not think we have looked fully at trying to drought proof Australia through the implementation of a national water strategy. That is a debate that deserves the attention of all Australians.

I will now address the final piece of legislation which we are considering in this cognate debate. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 covers a range of small changes to various primary industry acts. I will confine my comments this morning to the amendments proposed to the Farm Household Support Act 1992. This act governs the operation of the farm household support scheme, designed to provide assistance to farmers who are unable to meet day-to-day living expenses and who cannot access commercial finance. The scheme also provides a financial incentive for farmers wishing to leave the industry.

To qualify for farm household support, the applicant must be an Australian farmer between 16 years of age and the pension age, with a certificate of inability to obtain finance. The assistance is provided for a period of nine months. If during that time the farmer leaves the farm, the assistance becomes a grant. If the farmer remains in the industry, the assistance must be repaid at commercial interest rates. Those who leave the industry within the nine-month period will receive the balance payable for the period as a lump sum, in addition to their re-establishment grant of $45,000.

This bill makes a small but important change to the administrative arrangements for farm household support. It extends, from 14 to 30 days, the time allowed for farm household support applicants to obtain a certificate of inability to access finance. A great number of farmers have experienced difficulty in obtaining a certificate within 14 days, owing largely to the obvious problems they face in physically accessing financial institutions. I am pleased that the government has acknowledged this difficulty and acted in the manner that it has in this bill.

Although the farm household support scheme is, in theory, a useful mode of assistance to farmers who face insurmountable financial difficulties, its practical application has proved to be thwarted by inconsistencies and anomalies. For example, the re-establishment payments are limited to one per farm, regardless of the number of people or families who work on that farm. In the event of two families running one farm in cooperation, only one can receive the re-establishment grant. One wonders what happens to the other family.

It also strikes me as particularly counterproductive for farm household support to be converted to a loan for those who do not leave farming. The assistance is provided, after all, for those who cannot obtain commercial finance. It seems perfectly obvious that the last thing these people need is another loan.

It is also important to remember that leaving farming is not such an easy task at the moment. Many producers right through the drought areas of Australia who make a decision to leave find it impossible to sell and liquidate their farm in order to move off that land within nine months. They have assets which may have a paper value but have no resale value in the current circumstances. So the legislation is quite ludicrous in its application.

Some drought-ravaged farmers literally cannot give their farms away. So despite their best efforts farmers will still find themselves unable to access further commercial finance and incurring another debt because they go over the nine-month limit for moving off their land. Their inability to access further finance is the reason they went onto farm household support in the first place but once they access farm household support they have their feet on the sticky paper and cannot get them off. Unable to access finance, they are caught in a trap, all of which demonstrates the government's insensitive treatment of farmers around Australia, particularly in these drought ravaged times.

It is not surprising then that only 392 farmers are currently accessing farm household support. The government itself estimated that at least 1,200 would access this support. Government members were congratulating themselves because they were going to be giving household support to farmers in these very difficult times, but the farmers know that once they access that farm household support it is a one-way ticket off the farm and that if they do not go they have incurred another loan, which will incur commercial rates of interest after nine months.

It is the policy of the coalition to allow farm household support to be provided as a grant for 12 months, irrespective of whether the farmer chooses to leave the industry. This clearly recognises the need to provide assistance to meet day-to-day needs without creating additional debts.

I will be moving an amendment on behalf of the coalition which encourages the government to adopt our strategy for administering farm household support. I would hope that the government will accept our amendment. Any of those government members who have been out to the drought areas and have been in touch with the farmers, the farm industry leaders and church organisations such as Lifeline and the Salvation Army will know that farm household support as it applies under government legislation is failing.

It is all very well to decide at a round table conference to give $25 million to ANL and to offer the people of Sydney $150 million overnight to remove the Cahill Expressway, but it is not good enough to support farm households with income support for 12 months without strings attached. This callous approach of the government must be changed. I hope the opposition's amendment will be accepted.

The amendment also calls on the government to modify the assets test applied to other forms of assistance. There is no doubt that the assets tests applied to benefits such as jobsearch, family payment and Austudy are denying farmers access to assistance to which they and their families are clearly entitled. I sincerely hope that the government addresses this problem in the course of its cabinet deliberations today.

The true tragedy is that whatever rabbit the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) are able to pull from the hat today, it will simply be too late for many farmers. It will certainly be too late for many students who have already been forced to interrupt their study program because their parents can no longer continue to keep them living away from home whilst they gain access to tertiary studies. It will be too late for those skilled and experienced farmers who have already left the industry. It will also be too late for the marriages and relationships which have endured unbearable strain over the past two, three and four years. The government must bear the full brunt of the blame for these consequences, most of which are due entirely to its inaction.

The Prime Minister made a statement that drought in this country is a normal occurrence and a part of rural life. I hope that, when he went to Central Queensland and the Darling Downs, what he saw there was not a normal part of rural life. The government's silence on this issue still indicates to the opposition that it does not understand the plight of those in rural Australia.

We are not only talking about those on the land. We are also talking about the small businesses in the country towns and the workers who work for those small businesses. In the country town of Augathella the other day, a small business person rang me and said that he had just shut his small business and put off his worker because he could not continue running his business in that country town. He also said that, in the last four months, seven families had just walked out of their homes and left the town. They could not sell their house. They could not get a job in the area. They have just walked out.

The ramifications of this drought go far beyond the farm gate. They are well into the small business sector of the nation, particularly in these drought areas. It is certainly impacting on many families, whether they own a small business or whether they have got a job working for someone in these rural drought areas. I think the full impact of this drought and the drift of population from rural areas will be measured for many years to come.

All Australians are waiting to hear what the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy say today in the package for rural families affected by drought. The package has to extend to assistance to small business. It has got to extend into the area of welfare and it has got to extend into the farmer's financial problems. It has to address those problems. It really took a television personality and Australia wide support for a farmhand appeal before we saw a government willing to move and to visit the drought areas of this nation. I think it is a great tragedy that a government and a Prime Minister could be so out of touch that it took a television personality and the Australian people's contribution to that farmhand appeal to drag in the Prime Minister, albeit in a damage control mode, to see first-hand what was happening to families, small businesses and farmers in drought ravaged Australia. Whilst the coalition will not be denying this bill a second reading, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee, recognising the needs of individuals and families living in rural and regional Australia who face the ravages of severe drought, calls on the Government to make farm household support a grant for up to 12 months and to modify the assets test for other forms of assistance".

I hope the government will accept that amendment. If it does not, and if it does not address those issues in the package today, the opposition will be pursuing the government relentlessly on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time I have spoken in the Main Committee room, so please alert me if I make mistakes. I rise to support the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. I will not be supporting the amendment as proposed by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). I anticipate that the package that the cabinet is deliberating on and will announce will take on board the concerns registered by the member for Maranoa. I do not believe his suggestion is the way to handle this problem, although I recognise that there are problems associated with the farm household support scheme. It should be noted that this was an attempt to provide for those families who need to be assisted to leave a primary industry. We do not do it in any other industrial sector.

PARA.TAB: The speech by the honourable member for Maranoa, which we all suffered in silence, and the MPI in the House of Representatives yesterday are desperate attempts by those in the National Party to play catch-up. Once again, they have lost the initiative and they have dealt themselves out of the main game.

I want to make some comments about the member for Maranoa and, to an extent, some media misrepresentation of comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in my electorate on 19 July in relation to drought. The Prime Minister has not changed his position. In response to a question on the drought, he said that drought is a continuing factor in this nation. I have spoken to primary producers in central and western Queensland about seasons, and they are the first to admit that this has been a major problem over 60 years on the one land-holding, that often properties are more in drought than out of it, and that across the country at some point in time, and even in the same regions, drought declarations happen very frequently.

The Prime Minister's view is that this government will be about bringing in a systemic set of provisions to deal with a very complex issue in our agricultural sector. I think it would be useful to comment on the sort of policy on the run that the National Party is into. We should not look to the Queensland Country Life, which is the bible of most rural producers. It is not surprising to see that the constituency of the National Farmers Federation is sometimes behind its leaders. This was brought home to me during the Prime Minister's tour to central Queensland with representatives from the National Farmers Federation, the Queensland Grains Council and the United Graziers Association. We should not be surprised that peak leaders of organisations are often further advanced in their views because they have the bigger picture.

Let me refer, Mr Deputy Speaker, to an article by the Australian's rural writer, Tim Stevens, on 9 September. I happened to be reading this while I was on a flight with the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) out of Townsville to Charters Towers and to Clermont to visit droughted properties and to talk with local government and rural producers in central western Queensland. The aim of that visit was to further inform other cabinet members on the issues of the drought. It is simply not the case that this government is not interested or sensitive to drought issues. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, has been into my electorate—and, indeed, into the member for Maranoa's electorate—at least twice this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twice with no action.

—That is not the case, and the proof of the pudding will be in the eating when the cabinet brings down the results of its deliberations today. But let us see what a real critique of National Party policy on drought is all about. I quote from Tim Stevens's article, which I had the pleasure to show to the Attorney-General as we flew out of Townsville:

PARA.TAB: It is not often that a conservative politician bearing $90 million in gifts is shown the door by farm leaders. Yet this was the reaction from Coalition backbenchers and the National Farmers Federation to the release of the Opposition's drought policy last week.

The policy's key feature, a $90 million scheme to pay for fodder for livestock in "severe" drought areas, was interpreted as a blatant reversion by the Liberal and National parties to the days of unfunded promises, when policies were based overwhelmingly on populist agrarian notions rather than sounder economic rationales.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that when the Prime Minister visited and talked with farming families near Dingo he made the point that he was not going to be into cheap gestures and feel-good policies. What this government is about is sound, economically based policies that will provide significant assistance to farming families and to the agricultural sector. Why was this critique made? It was apparently decided on 22 August by a shadow cabinet meeting that drought was obviously going to be a key issue. I quote:

It was decided that a comprehensive response was needed of the Government's policies and this was interpreted by John Anderson, the Coalition's primary industries spokesman, as a desire to have a detailed policy and off he went to find one.

What the primary industries spokesman came up with was apparently the Fightback package plus this fodder subsidy scheme, which is really revisiting the Fraser government's 1982 scheme. Fodder subsidies have been criticised for the following reasons, and I once again quote Mr Stevens:

PARA.TAB: .They provide a disincentive for producers to prepare for drought, which includes the making and storing of hay.
.They tend to jolt demand, sending fodder prices through the roof.
.Fodder suppliers and users have rorted the system.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go on quoting Mr Stevens:

PARA.TAB: Curiously, Anderson mentioned his policies to no one. Despite the stated desire of Opposition Leader Alexander Downer to involve all of the Liberal and National party political processes in decision-making, The Australian has been unable to speak to anyone whose views were sought on drought issues prior to the announcement.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation was not consulted. The shadow minister did not bother to go on and consult the peak organisation, and in public and in private—although not quoted in the Queensland Country Life—the peak farming bodies of this country were scathing in their criticism. I further quote Mr Stevens:

PARA.TAB: The chairman of the Coalition parliamentary primary industries committee, Neil Andrew—

SPEECH.PARA: who I see is in the Main Committee room today—
first knew of the policy on the morning of its release. Embarrassingly, Andrew was later asked to sit next to Anderson during the press conference.

PARA.TAB: Little time was spent debating the policy in the shadow Cabinet of August 29, despite the potential fiscal size of the package, although one proposal from Anderson for concessional loans—to help reconstruct the sector after the drought ends—was sent to a special shadow Cabinet sub-committee. The rest was ticked and sent to a joint meeting of the Liberal National parties the next day, before being released just over one week after shadow Cabinet first asked for a policy.
Apparently, this is the way the Coalition's policy making process works these days. There were no offsets sought by shadow Cabinet to counterbalance the increased expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: They are all care and no responsibility in the opposition. Mr Stevens continues:
The Nationals, it appears on the surface, have reverted to the good old days of pork barrelling and unfunded campaign promises, with the blessing of the Liberals.
This, Mr Deputy Speaker, is the sorry state of opposition policy building. This is the policy you have when you try to have a policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your policy.

—We are going to have an excellent policy. The Prime Minister's tour was not brought on by the media; it was brought on because the Labor government has more rural representatives in this parliament than the National Party does, and we have a vested interest in making sure that the concerns of the rural and agricultural sector of this country are taken into account. But it will not be done by feel-good throwing money at the problem. It will be done by a systematic approach, to provide effective changes to the rural adjustment scheme and effective responses to the obvious needs and pressures on farm families.

PARA.TAB: One of the factors that I have certainly put forward, apart from looking at an effective way to make sure that the children of farming families are able to access assistance with their schooling, is an issue that has not made the headlines but was put to us at a property south of Charters Towers. It is that we are not talking about only the education of older children, who will need to go away to boarding school to get an education. It is vital that those children do get that education, because it is very clear that many of those children will choose not to return to family properties. They will choose to go into other sectors of the economy. Like all other children in this country, they need to have access to educational opportunities, in order to either choose to go into other sectors or become effective farm managers. Gone are the days when people could go to year 10 and then just go back and learn the job from their parents. The farm sector, like every other industrial sector, has to change and become much more effective in terms of targeting niche markets and so on. It is now a highly skilled operation.

But I want to make comment on those children who are being educated at home. The story I want to tell the members attending the Main Committee this morning is one of a young mother who came to the meeting with a 10-week-old baby, the fourth of her children; she had three other children at home. She was lucky enough to have her mother staying with her prior to the birth of this baby, and subsequent to its birth. This young mother is teaching the seven-year-old at home. Nowadays, that is a full day's occupation. It is not just a matter of setting up some work and going away to do the housework; you are in the schoolroom all day. The second child has been classified as a gifted child, and will, therefore, need particular assistance if its abilities are going to be really provided for. The third child is a toddler.

Now, a mother with a 10-week-old baby should be, basically, doing what she can in the house and then feeding that baby and looking after it. At the point in time when this mother came to this meeting with the Attorney-General and myself, her husband had cattle away on agistment, so the only support person she had to look after herself and her four children was her mother. Had her mother not been available, I do not know who would have washed the nappies. I have drawn to the attention of the Prime Minister and other members of the cabinet that we must make sure we are providing for support so that women in this kind of predicament can access assistance. Obviously, it is difficult for families with young children when they drive into town—which may be a two- or three-hour drive—to go to the doctor, just to arrange for occasional child care. At least in Charters Towers there are some doctors who bulk-bill. In many cases in country Queensland, and certainly in Rockhampton, there are almost no doctors who bulk-bill, causing further financial pressure on these families.

I can assure members opposite that these family concerns are being addressed, and certainly were addressed by the Prime Minister. As I said yesterday in the caucus meeting, it was very interesting that what was said on the national media was very true during our visit to Timbaroo at Dingo. Farming families were really quite shocked by the fact that, in meeting the Prime Minister, they had to wrestle with their preconceptions about the sort of person he was. Of course, their preconceptions had been based on television media presentations of the Prime Minister, and articles in magazines such as the Queensland Country Life. What they found was a warm, caring, concerned person who spoke with feeling and was able to yarn on their level. That has been a very important experience for that group of people. I assure you that the Prime Minister is not someone who flourishes a bit of rhetoric just to provide a bit of popular grandstanding.

The key point he made at that meeting was: just as we made a commitment not to leave the unemployed behind, we will not leave country people behind. We are aware of the concerns and we will respond to those concerns. We do not need the National Party to bleat here today and to play catch-up to tell this government what is required to provide for people through this drought.

One of the issues that I have raised with the Prime Minister is that, as we look at the crisis and the tragedy that is happening to people in this drought, we will certainly have to look at issues about land care and environmental degradation. I will just quote from the minister's second reading speech. In connection with the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly they will ensure that ecologically sustainable development principles are written into the charter of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation and that the membership of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation will include, in future, expertise in environmental and ecological matters.

This is going to be an issue that has certainly been brought into stark relief by the drought. What we see, following the extension of rural and agricultural pursuits into marginal country, particularly across northern Queensland, is that where we have drought conditions we have a major long-term impact on the environmental status of the land. An example would have been when Capella, which has had drought for six to eight seasons, got a deluge of rain—seven inches in 24 hours. This is pretty typical; it is up the road from Emerald. In a good season, it is one of the most beautiful areas of this country. If we have a droughted area with extensive clearing and then there is a deluge of rain, we have a massive erosion problem. This is a factor that will have to be addressed and will be addressed by this government. We cannot simply allow extension of dry land farming into marginal areas if we expect to keep this country together, ecologically speaking.

PARA.TAB: I will quote from an article by Wallace Brown in the Sunday Mail on 4 September. He was being critical that there was not an effective drought policy. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the latest survey by the National Farmers' Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, being joint sponsors of the Landcare program, shows increasing desertification due to clearing of trees and other native vegetation.

PARA.TAB: It is alarming to read that 5000 square km of native vegetation is still being cleared each year in Australia, and that this is an amount comparable to the area cleared in the Amazon Basin, which environmentalists world-wide condemn.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to face the fact that we have to get back to restoring this country to ecologically sustainable development. Now, belatedly I believe, farming organisations and the National Farmers Federation have come on board on this. This is a very important issue in the government's drought policy. It is not going to be more dams, more water. I have had well-meaning and very caring people who want to train water into rural sectors.

PARA.TAB: It is good to see, as unfortunate as it is, that at this time of drought there are very few cattle in the middle of my electorate because the land simply cannot sustain those cattle. We have to recognise that. Yes, indeed, we have to look after breeding stock, but we will not do it by the ill-thought out, ill-considered policies with which the National Party is desperately trying to hold on to its constituency. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, at the end of the day, the Labor government is increasingly going to take on board that rural constituency. In fact, one of the farmers at the Dingo meeting said to the Prime Minister that he may well be the Prime Minister who saves the bush. As the Prime Minister said in response, that is a very big ask but it will be this government which will put forward very positive policies that will be to the long-term benefit of the rural sector and ecologically sustainable development in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest Mr J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) to be a decent person but it saddens me that she would stoop to such cheap politics as the contribution we have just heard from her. In fact, it has taken some constraint on my part to listen to her in silence. I think the member for Capricornia should go out and ask the people on the ground what they think of the initiative we are calling for. Go and ask the constituents of the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). Go and ask the real people. If the member for Capricornia is so fond of quoting newspaper articles, let me quote to her this one from the Queensland Country Life. This is a newspaper from her own state. She should stay and hear this contribution. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A fodder subsidy for drought stricken graziers is one of the most positive and effective forms of assistance.

PARA.TAB: Federal Primary Industries Minister, Bob Collins, is wrong to dismiss it out of hand because it would not work.

SPEECH.PARA: This was on 8 September. It also states:
So why is our national Government so out of step with the opinions of its citizens, choosing instead to fiddle while rural Australia withers?

That is by the editor of the Queensland Country Life. If the member for Capricornia is genuine in her sentiments that the Labor Party is going to meet the needs of rural Australia, it ought to be a lot more in touch with what the people there think of its government. People are asking: why can decisions be made, on the run and outside cabinet, that can contribute $150 million to a so-called eyesore in Sydney? This decision was made on the run, outside the executive, by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). How can sweetheart deals outside cabinet and outside the parliament be made on the run with the Maritime Union of Australia? How can those decisions be made on the run?

PARA.TAB: There are desperate primary producers in the member for Maranoa's electorate. Sadly, the cancerous drought is spreading all the way through New South Wales. Now even in my own electorate of Mallee there will be grain growers who will not harvest wheat or grain of any sort this year because the drought is extending across Australia. They are asking: why do we have to wait three years for decent consideration? This drought has not suddenly arrived.

These are the sorts of questions the constituency is asking. It is a pity the member for Capricornia has not stayed. I would suggest that she should get out there and ask the people what they think of the initiatives we announced. Rural Australia is not outer suburbia. Rural Australia is the people out there producing the wealth in the sparsely populated areas of Australia. I think the Labor Party has got a lot of work to do if it thinks it can sustain the confidence of rural Australia. I am not talking about urban suburbs. We are talking about rural Australia where there are 130,000 people in 70-odd thousand square kilometres that are sparsely populated but produce the nation's wealth. They want to know why the government can be so hypocritical in its efforts to help its union mates and to preserve the aesthetics for the Prime Minister when they have to wait for decent consideration.

They have been earning this nation's wealth for years—paying for the excessive income we have for imported goods—and they are asking for better consideration and a better deal. I would have expected a better contribution from the member for Capricornia. I will leave it to other members from our side who are present to talk more about the initiatives in our policy other than the fodder subsidy. We talk about reinstalling drought in the national disasters relief arrangements. For the Prime Minister to say that primary producers are expected to prepare for four years of drought indicates how out of touch he is. He has got a long way to go if he is going to save the bush, as the member for Maranoa has said.

I will get back to the legislation that is before this Committee, and the motion that the member for Maranoa has put before it. It is true that the majority of the bills that we are considering, particularly those that relate to levies, have general industry support. For someone in a very strong horticultural producing electorate, and especially in regard to wine—

TALK.START.PARA: —Great wine.

—Great wine from the Mallee areas. Thank you to the member for Maranoa, who was in my electorate for two days last week. We did enjoy the fruit of the vine. The sad contrast was that, with the advantages and asset of the Murray River as an irrigation source, 50 kilometres to the south, we will see grain growers feeding their wheat to their sheep. This is the sad plight of the extension of this drought. I do not think that the Prime Minister—nor the members present, obviously, from the contribution we have just heard—has yet appreciated how insidiously the drought is extending right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: In Swan Hill, my home city, we have a large agricultural machinery producer, producing disc ploughs and marketing right across Australia, to Western Australia, Queensland and indeed, recently, even expanding into exporting. Sadly, a fortnight ago, the firm had to put off five young people, including one apprentice, because of the impact of the drought. That is the extent of the national disaster. It is not just a problem for the Queenslanders. We have heard the stories from members representing those areas—but the drought does extend. There are now five families in Swan Hill upon which the drought has had a direct impact. Their income will be reduced to the extent that they will not be spending in Swan Hill, and so other businesses are impacted by the effects of the drought. It is a national disaster—we have said clearly that this should be recognised.

Irrigation from the Murray River, as I have said, is one of the saving resources of an electorate like mine, which is so dependent on the elements. The member for Maranoa has spoken about a number of my industries. He has referred to chickens, and I would much rather focus on horticulture. No-one was more disappointed than me, when I arrived here as a new member of parliament, to listen to the government's August budget in 1993, and hear its proposals to tax the wine industry. The member for Maranoa has already spoken in glowing terms about the expansion that this industry is providing in wealth earning and job creation. The objective of this industry is, by the turn of the century, to triple its export development, which is the billion dollar program that the member for Maranoa has mentioned to the Committee.

To see a government picking a winner here, and then choosing to tax it with a WST, instead of a GST—the wholesale sales tax on wine—disappoints me. This is a government that purports to want to initiate regional development and to have an interest in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They said there would be no new taxes.

—A government that went to an electorate and said there would be no new taxes, and yet one of the first industries it seeks to tax with a broad base consumption tax—the very tax that it lied about to the electorate—is an industry that is so significant in my electorate. Those people out there will be a long time forgetting that lie. As I have said earlier, this government has got a long way to go before it can convince the people of my constituency that it is the government that can save the bush.

PARA.TAB: In my home town of Red Cliffs, Lindemans wines some 20-odd years ago invested substantial amounts in infrastructure and can now boast one of the largest wineries in the southern hemisphere. Subsequent owners of that winery have continued to invest, because they see real opportunities in meeting the targets in the expansion of the wine industry generally. The employment base that that winery now provides to a small community like Red Cliffs, a small rural town which has a population of around about 1,500, is worth millions of dollars to that community.

This is an example of real regional development in the most successful terms. I think the government needs to recognise this and encourage enterprises at every opportunity. That is real regional development, that is development that creates jobs. The prospect of a prosperous future in wine grape production gives the community some sense of optimism for the future. I therefore suggest to the government, and those of its members that are present here today, that on all occasions it should work very carefully, through its taxation policies, to ensure that bright, new, expansive industries are encouraged in every way.

I would like to comment further on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I know that other speakers following will probably do the subject more justice than I can, and the member for Maranoa has already commented on it, but I would like give my observations on how the farm household support scheme is not working. I continue to focus on horticulture. Around the Sunraysia region of my electorate, I have got two principal industries, citrus and dried vine fruit. Both these industries have been asked to bear the pain of being sacrificed on the great altar of free trade. I was annoyed last week, when there were negotiations in respect of the Australian National Line, to hear the union movement arguing its case, saying that its people could not be expected to compete with Third World labour rates. I feel that it is gross hypocrisy that the government has listened to this argument and invested substantial amounts of taxpayers' funds to preserve jobs in that industry. Yet my two industries, worth probably $200 to $250 million dollars per annum just in my electorate, are being asked to compete with cheap labour from Turkey in regard to dried vine fruit and extremely cheap labour and the benefits of critical mass out of Brazil in respect of citrus.

I ask the government how it can tolerate this style of hypocrisy. Many of my constituents would say that, true, the ultimate goal must be world free trade and a level playing field and that we are going to have a considerable amount of pain in getting there. They would not mind bearing some of this pain, provided it is shared by all Australians. When an announcement is made outside the cabinet and outside the parliament in regard to the Australian National Line, they just see gross hypocrisy, given that for years now they have been asked to bear considerable pain, go without and even have to suffer the indignity of deciding which of their children will be able to pursue tertiary education. That is a terrible decision for parents to have to make.

Many of them, particularly in dried vine fruit, elected to take the option in regard to farm household support. Sadly, the situation is that, whilst they were genuine initially in their efforts to discharge their obligation in respect of the ownership of their property, the market is such that there are probably something like 1,000 dried vine fruit properties on the market in the Sunraysia district and properties just do not sell. We have now got a significant number of people who have taken farm household support, gone beyond their nine months, cannot sell their properties and now have to sustain what is being transferred as a commercial loan at commercial interest rates, rates well in excess of 10 per cent. This is an added financial burden on their ability to cope or even to consider how they can restructure and be part of a new industry and to take the opportunities that wine grapes are providing for them.

In view of their significant debt as well as this additional debt to the rural finance corporation, I am very concerned about their ability to meet this exciting new initiative in wine grapes, so I put to the government that it should give greater consideration to the wealth producers of my electorate as well as consider the national disaster that this drought represents. I also suggest that when it makes its announcements it should defend itself with respect to the time it has taken to announce drought policy to meet the needs of hurting people, particularly Queenslanders and people from New South Wales, because those people can see hypocrisy in terms of the way the government assists its friends.

I also remind members of the government of a number of problems with regard to salinity control and the sustaining of water reserves in the Murray-Darling Basin. In fact, this summer there is no doubt that the Darling River will have a blue-green algal burst that will see the last one in 1992 fade into insignificance.

My horticulturalists are being asked to contribute to salinity mitigation from a variety of sources, but to do so while their financial circumstances are so fragile is an additional burden they cannot sustain. Some are being asked to contribute to modifications to their supply system where open channels are being converted to pipelines, which often requires a capital cost contribution. Others are being asked to make contributions through local government levies through their municipal rates. I put it to the government that the ability of the horticulturalists to meet these contributions has been substantially eroded by years of neglect and that it is time that the Minister for Resources, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), and the government considered the dried vine fruit growers and citrus growers in my electorate.

This Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill is primarily designed to meet the needs of the drought stricken farmers but it also provides a basis on which we can meet the urgent needs of primary industry in general. We are talking about industries that are essential to the small communities they surround. Every retailer in a community where primary commodities are not doing well is also not doing well so we are speaking on behalf of small business across rural Australia as well as the primary producers themselves. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues from both sides of the House, I would hope, in supporting the bills that are before the Main Committee this morning. If ever I have seen something which epitomises a bunch of Johnny-come-latelys chasing after the bus waving a ticket in the air, it would have to be the amendment which has been moved by the member for Maranoa, Mr Scott.
—That has been our policy for years.
—Larry-come-latelys.
—According to the member for Page, Mr Woods, Larry-come-latelys might be the term, but we should not go down that track. Let me say—
—A point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. That has actually been coalition policy since 1990.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your deliberations and for the accuracy of them. The bills that have been introduced by the government and supported, I thought, by the opposition do allow some finetuning to various bills and bring them up to date with requirements of primary industries. The bills cover seemingly small amendments to achieve that finetuning in various areas. Some of them impact in my electorate; many of them do not. Nevertheless, as one of the many country Labor members of the government I appreciate their impact right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 has been slightly amended. I would like to add my words of support for this amendment. It changes the definition of `winemaker' to `producer'. It changes the words in the act from `winemaker' to `producer' and that small redefinition within the act does bring in many of the players in the industry who were previously barred from having a say. They can now have a say in the direction of that industry.

The wine industry itself has been the subject of much debate, particularly in the last 18 months in regard to some of the changes that the government has proposed at different times. It is recognised as a very strong, vigorous industry of great benefit to Australia, particularly to the various electorates that honourable members on both sides of this chamber represent.

No doubt the amount of money that comes in from export earnings through value adding and sales overseas has been a great boon to the economy of Australia. It is most important that the changes we have put in place ensure that that industry continues its vigorous growth into the future. The predictions of sales, both overseas and domestic, indicate that the industry is quite capable of achieving and maintaining its growth. The investment within the industry indicates that there are plenty of other people out there who have an opinion on where the industry can go. It is the same opinion that I have and my colleagues on both sides of the house no doubt share.

Whilst my electorate does not have any of the wine grapes and brandy industries contained within it, grapes are grown not far away in the state of Queensland. Probably not too many people go into bat for that industry up there in the sunny hills of the Stanthorpe area. A couple of wineries that I am familiar with have certainly achieved great advancements in both their quality and their production techniques. Some of them have actually achieved national recognition albeit only very small. Nevertheless, through its educative and technical expertise, the industry is now exporting quite strongly offshore.

We tend to think that Australia is a little bit too free and easy with its technical expertise in the sense that we are quite ready to share our expertise with overseas producers so that they become our competitors in some way. However, we seem to be holding our own with the quality and the value for quality wines that we are exporting.

In terms of other bills, the farm household support scheme has come in for some debate here this morning. The changes to that are just one part of the whole package of support which is available to rural industries and which, no doubt, will be further expanded in the announcements that I would expect to come from the government today.

I am confident that some of the changes that are mooted will further extend the government's position as a government which is able to listen and to deliver policies of support to various industries that might be running into difficulty, particularly the workers and the employers in those industries. If there was anything which the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) hinted at in her fine contribution to this debate this morning, it was the fact that the government already has in place many policies which are assisting farm families and workers in rural industries across Australia, particularly those that are affected by drought. The response from any government of any persuasion should never be a hip-pocket response to cast money towards the problem and simply to pretend that that is all it has to do.

If there is one thing which has marked responses in the past, it has been that that sort of policy and something like the fodder subsidy which has been bandied about in the last few days, both within the House and in the media, have not produced productive responses or results in the long run. The member for Maranoa in his contribution this morning hinted at the effects of inflation that will be flowing through the Australian economy as a result of the drought and the subsequent increase in prices. A simple thing like a drought subsidy, when it is abused, does not necessarily reduce the price of fodder to a particular farmer or farming enterprise and, itself, if it is abused, has obviously contributed to the flow-on effects of inflation.

When the member for Maranoa was waxing lyrical about the effects of inflation, flow-on effects and the containment of costs in that area, I really took a big breath and thought he was going to go all the way. But instead he took a little diversion and went back to the National Party's pet subject, the impact of what he perceives as the effects of work practices on costs of primary producers. In terms of the shortage of grain, particularly feed grain to industries, that flow-on effect is something which is very real.

The reason I took a big breath is that I thought the member for Maranoa was going to go on and elaborate a little bit more on the effects of the increase in grain price on other industries. As the chicken meat industry is another industry that is affected by one of these bills, the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill, I thought the member for Maranoa may have said a little bit about the impost of that increase in grain price on the chicken meat industry. Whatever perceived inadequacies the member for Maranoa attempted to allude to in his contribution this morning with regard to work practices that he thought had to be changed, without his actually spelling out what they are, certainly the impost of the increased price of feed grain going into the chicken industry is something which that industry is most concerned about. The member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) is going to correct me because he is an expert on this, but the elasticity in the price of chicken meat means that, as the price of chicken meat goes up even a moderate amount, consumers will swing away to other meat products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the member is absolutely right.

—The biggest impost that is already flowing through is the increase in grain prices, and that particular aspect is going to be felt in the demand from consumers. That is what the chicken industry is most concerned about. Perhaps the member for Maranoa shied away from it, but perhaps he was also alluding to the fact that if we were to import grain we might be able to keep that price down.
—He actually did refer to pricing policy.

—I am adding a little bit more to what he may have been alluding to, though not prepared to say, because I have a strong chicken meat processing industry in my electorate, as does the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods).

PARA.TAB: Mr Bradford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got more than that for the member for McPherson; I can assure him of that. We have very strong rural industries in my electorate and that of the member for Page, who so ably represents those industries that are present in his electorate. Let me mention Sunnybrand Chickens, which is located at Byron Bay. It is a fine industry. It has grown over the last 20 years to be a major employer and supplier of meat chickens along the north coast—
—And a grower of chicken hatchlings.

—And a grower of chicken hatchlings, I think we might call them for want of a better term. That particular industry is a substantial employer and supplier in the electorate, and I take exception to the member for Maranoa alluding in the way he did to the work practices which he saw as a threat. That industry has grown substantially with good work from the management and the employees. Just a few months ago the member for Page and I had the honour to have a meeting with the management of Sunnybrand Chickens—
—And a lovely lunch.

—And we had an excellent lunch based on various value adding types of chicken which they are selling to the market. I do not know whether, under the present debate on some other laws, the honourable member for Page and I must declare that lunch. Nevertheless, I would like to point out that over our luncheon we were able to discuss with the management, and also with DEET officers who were present, the way in which the government employment schemes have been able to assist the business—through training and wage subsidies and so forth—to take on and reskill staff to step up into the new demands of that industry.

PARA.TAB: The industry has changed substantially, particularly in the last 10 years, towards value adding. It is no longer simply selling bodies of chickens in the different sizes that we might be familiar with and that were presented in the supermarket for many years. The business is actually deboning and doing all sorts of other things to the chicken meat to make it more presentable and much more attractive to the purchaser, and it is competing with the other meat industries which are also present in my electorate and that of the honourable member for Page and also in the electorates of the members on the other side. I refer, obviously, to the pork, lamb and beef industries.

Nevertheless, the changes to the national residue survey administration for the meat chicken industry have been accepted by industry players across Australia. Obviously, with the support of the members on both sides of the House, these bills will go through and will, I hope, further add to the strength of the industry itself.

There have been various comments made about the timeliness of the farm household support changes which are contained within these bills. As I mentioned earlier in my discussions here this morning, the changes add to what is already in place to assist farm families and employers across Australia in rural industries which are affected by the drought. I am fortunate, in the sense that mine is probably the only electorate in New South Wales which has not been drought declared. If there are other such electorates, they might be Sydney itself and right down the bottom in the southern parts of Australia. I certainly appreciate the difficulties that the electorates of the honourable member for Page and the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), and the industries in those areas, are facing.

The various changes which are in place for farm household support are all about assisting farm families. The almost nigglingly small change which has been put forward in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Maranoa—without any explanation as to why he was tweaking it up that extra very small amount—is a bit of a kite flying exercise. The other part of the amendment which has been moved is something which has already been flagged very strongly in the media and through the Labor caucus as something that we were quite strongly prepared to do, and I look forward to seeing the announcements this afternoon.

Why not accept these amendments? Because they do not actually relate to the bill which would require amendment in here, and hence they are a little out of place and are certainly out of keeping with the nature of the debate which is normally allowed for in this chamber. The series of bills, as I said in my introduction, is simply some finetuning of aspects of various bills for the primary industries. Without doubt, members on both sides—despite what has been moved here this morning—will be supporting them, and I do so as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to take some umbrage at the comments made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) and by my friend the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell). I particularly take umbrage at the member for Richmond's illustration of the opposition—a coalition, I hasten to remind him—as the Johnny-come-latelys who are running behind the bus and waving a ticket saying, `We missed out.' I happen to think that it is almost indecent for anyone to rise in this Main Committee chamber or in the House, in the light of the present disaster of the drought, and claim to have some sort of monopoly on rural wisdom or on the way in which assistance should be offered.

PARA.TAB: The cruel reality is that none of us has got anything to brag about. We have all responded belatedly to a desperate need in rural Australia. I think it is quite improper for the member for Capricornia to suggest there should be, in some sense, an apology from the opposition for having pursued the issues it pursued in order to get recognition of what was happening with the drought. It is equally improper, if I may say so, for the member for Richmond to suggest that in some way there is something superbly better about the government's package, and awfully inferior about the opposition's. I was having some difficulty in finding an appropriate analogy but it struck me that it was almost like both of us wandering around Rwanda with a bag full of rice, with one team saying to the other, `We've got a more attractive ladle for doling out the rice than you.'

Frankly, we have a nation with a real, acute, almost insurmountable problem that calls, in this instance, for a parliamentary reaction—not a government or an opposition reaction. I was not amused, though not entirely surprised, that the member for Capricornia—not uncharitably, I hasten to add, but nonetheless in a rather political exercise—read from an editorial by Tim Stevens referring to the coalition's drought policy. In it I was quoted by Mr Stevens as not having been adequately consulted—as the counterpart in the coalition, as it were, of the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods)—on the question of the coalition's drought policy.

It is perfectly true for Mr Stevens to say that I was not consulted. In fact, he rang me after the drought policy had been announced and asked whether I or my committee had been consulted. He said that it had been intimated to him that we had not been. I indicated that, no, we had not been. But I was not offended by that. I recognised that the shadow minister for primary industry had a deadline to meet; that he had taken the policy to the shadow cabinet and it had met with shadow cabinet approval; that it had not been unfunded, as alleged by Mr Stevens or by the member for Capricornia, in that he had also sought and gained the approval of the shadow treasurer; and that it came to me prior to its release so that it could be reviewed.

There simply was not a time to call the committee together and, as anyone from the coalition would attest, it has not been a matter of any tension between coalition members or between members of the Liberal and National parties independently. To suggest that I was sitting there uneasily alongside the shadow minister for primary industry at this press conference would be something of a misnomer, I have to confess. Those who know me well enough know I am sufficient of a politician not to be uneasy about any sort of publicity. I must add that there was some contest for the opportunity to be seated alongside the shadow minister for primary industry, a contest I am pleased to say I won.

However, I want to pick up the point made by the member for Capricornia and run from time to time by members opposite, suggesting that in some way the National Farmers Federation and all farming bodies have suggested the coalition was way off course with its particular version of the way in which the desperate need facing Australian farmers should be met. Can I say that my experience, from conversations with the National Farmers Federation representatives of recent times, has been that they are regretting their rather outspoken criticism of only one sector of the coalition's proposal—the proposal for fodder subsidy. My own farmers organisation, the South Australian Farmers Federation, has from day one endorsed and embraced this entire package.

Lest I fall into the same trap as I am accusing my friends opposite of having entered, this is not a case of saying, `Look how much better our policy is than yours.' This is a case of the coalition members standing here and saying that there is a desperate need. We recognise that the government is taking steps to address that need, and we believe that changes could be made to improve the way in which the need, which is currently felt by drought stricken farmers across Australia, is addressed.

One of those changes has been addressed by the member for Richmond. In his closing remarks, I think he said it was `niggardly small', meaning it was a very small change that the coalition was seeking. In the light of that debate, I simply ask: if that is the case, why is it that the government has so much trouble accepting this coalition amendment? The coalition does not seek a great deal. It seeks simply to improve the way in which farm household support is made available to farmers and to extend the period of availability, without strings attached, to 12 months instead of nine months.

That is not an unreasonable request, but it is dismissed out of hand by the government as if anything proposed by the coalition was bound to be the wrong thing to do. I find that a difficult exercise to come to terms with because—rather like the land grant—here I am as part of the coalition saying, `We accept that these things need to happen, so let us see if we can improve on them'; but I have a government not even entertaining my amendment. I must say I find that somewhat disappointing.

The member for Capricornia was also very critical of what she saw as the coalition's reaction to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that he would not leave country people behind. Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, the problem is simply this: we are facing a drought that is now four years old. We would be failing in our role as the coalition if we had not been

SPEECH.PARA: prodding and poking the Prime Minister into taking action, and we would be failing today if we were simply observing that it took him longer than it should have taken him to be aware of what is happening, particularly in Queensland and in northern New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: It was said by the member of Capricornia that when the people of Queensland met the Prime Minister face to face they found that the preconceptions they had of him were without foundation and that he was really quite a gregarious fellow. I am genuinely pleased that that is the case. It is a comment that after 11 years in this place as a member of the federal parliament I could have made, and have made from time to time, about the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. I am sorry to say that it is a comment I find it more difficult to make about the present Prime Minister; not because I want to be critical, but because after 11 years in this place I have never had an opportunity to experience what I do not doubt is his capacity to be gregarious. It is but something he never extends in any sense to coalition members. The preconception that is abroad in the community is very much the result of the way the Prime Minister deals with us, rather than something that we have sought deliberately to cultivate or foster.

The changes that the coalition is seeking are, in the words of the member for Richmond, small changes. We believe they improve the way in which assistance will be delivered to people in drought stricken Queensland and New South Wales, and for that reason we are proposing these amendments and seeking government support for them. We are certainly not seeking to have them dismissed out of hand, as seems to have been the case to date.

In addressing this debate the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) touched on the crux of the matter: which is, as he said, that only 392 people are currently accessing farm household support. That tells its own story. Clearly, farm household support is not doing what the government intended it should do, and it needs to be amended. We seek to amend it by extending its availability and not making it such a one-way ticket off the farm for those who are dependent on it. We have also sought some changes to the re-establishment grant, because we feel there is a certain inflexibility in making the approximately $45,000 available to only one farming family, when in many instances the farm is managed by more than one farming family and some additional support is needed where additional families are being forced off the farm.

I do not wish to spend much longer dealing with the question of drought, but everyone agrees—government and opposition—that drought is a seasonal matter and that it is reasonable to expect farmers to farm in an Australian climate anticipating that a drought will arrive.
