For example, there has not been any effort by the coalition to suggest to the government that it ought currently to be intervening in the drought stricken state of South Australia, because this is the first year in which South Australia has found itself in drought. As a coalition, we have endeavoured to be realistic about the way in which drought policy is delivered, recognising that Australian farmers must expect to face drought from time to time.

There are, however, two difficulties. The first and more obvious one is that in the case of northern New South Wales and Queensland this is the fourth year of drought, so clearly any assistance is well and truly overdue. What is happening there, as both government and opposition recognise, is something that could not reasonably be budgeted for by anybody in any rural practice in Australia.

The second difficulty is harder to come to terms with. I do not have an answer to it, but I feel I have a responsibility to alert the government to the fact that in the case of South Australia, particularly on the west coast, there are those who this year face a drought from which they will not be able to recover any grain at all. In technical terms it is their first year in drought. Their financial difficulties are compounded by the fact that last year they lost much of their grain due to a mouse plague that consumed paddocks of grain and seemed to be very difficult to contain, and the year before—irony of ironies—they lost their grain because it rained persistently through November and December and the grain was destroyed. They have only had one year of drought, but they have had an unpredictable three years of low, minimal or almost non-existent income in some instances. This is an instance where it may not be appropriate to deliver any form of drought relief, but some form of farm household support is entirely appropriate. It would be much better if that farm household support did not carry with it the automatic obligation to leave the property.

Also, the government ought to be aware, as it considers its response to the drought, of instances where small businesses in rural Australia have experienced marginally better years, particularly over the last two years, and where a reasonable rainfall has, in some cases, meant sensible crops of oil seeds at tolerable prices. Those machinery dealers in regional Australia and, in some cases, those farmers will very likely face a provisional tax bill this year which they will be unable to meet simply because they will not have sufficient income. Therein lies a bind that the government ought to be conscious of as it puts together its rural policy.

There was some criticism levelled at farming generally by the member for Capricornia when she mentioned that one of the flow-on effects of drought is the erosion that occurs when large levels of rainfall follow a drought and soil is washed away. My experience with farming—which is now over 40 years—is that in almost all instances farmers are far more environmentally sensitive than ever they were. It is very rare for land to be cleared without good cause. In my own area of the mallee, where the rainfall may frequently be little more than nine inches, previous generations of farmers had an ongoing problem—it is a problem with which the member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) would be familiar—where the encroachment of sandhills became a problem simply because land had been cleared and then began to drift.

Thanks to the farming techniques of the 1990s, those problems have all but disappeared. Farmers who are now deliberating sowing drought tolerant crops, oats particularly, have been able to retrieve these sandhills. Far from drought causing additional soil erosion, although that is a possibility, the generation of farmers that we now represent as a parliament is a generation much less likely to get into trouble than their forefathers. Their forefathers simply lacked the techniques that are now in place to ensure that land erosion is a minimal problem.

I conclude by moving from the sublime to the ridiculous. We have been dealing with drought and I do not know quite how to link the rest of my remarks into my comments, except perhaps to refer to dry white wines, which is drawing a very long bow. Part of the legislation, as honourable members know, deals with the way in which a levy is to be collected from small winemakers and I want to pick up some of the comments made by the member for Mallee about the wine industry.

I am conscious of the fact that the wine industry has committed itself to a dramatic expansion program encouraged by the federal government and in South Australia encouraged by the Dean Brown state government. I have no doubt that could be reflected by other state governments around Australia as well. It is expected that during the 1990s an additional 20,000 hectares of wine grapes will come into production and that the value of wine grape production will go from $1.5 billion in 1993 to, it is hoped, $2.5 billion by the year 2000. I am a little bothered about this level of expansion, having been around long enough to have watched every primary industry go through cycles and to know that there is only one road from being up, and that is running down. I do not mean that as any criticism of the present government's policy—I think that we are wisely encouraging the wine industry to expand.

But there is one cautionary word I want to exercise in the context of this debate. Following the government's decision to call for an inquiry into the wine industry, it has suggested to the wine industry that it would be prepared to allow a depreciation allowance for new plantings. This did not exist in the past but it exists now, so new plantings occurring in the wine industry can be effectively depreciated and there can be a tax advantage in that planting process. I approve of that.

I would point out to the government, however, that the same sort of facility does not exist for the write-off in tree fruits and in dried vine fruits. I believe that currently we as a parliament, and the government particularly, are sending what is effectively the wrong signal to horticulturists and viticulturists around Australia, and it is placing a greater emphasis on wine grape expansion than is wise. The signal is, `We'll give you a tax write-off for this', but not a tax write-off for replacing, say, sultanas, currants, apricots, peaches, pears, normal market stone fruit or canning stone fruit production, or, for that matter, a write-off for citrus growers who may even, in the present climate, choose to expand.

I think that this is sending the wrong market signals and that we are having a greater emphasis placed on wine grapes than is wise, and the discerning growers may well choose to have a healthier mix of plantings if in fact the tax write-off were more evenly based. I would like to make that comment to the government and challenge it to pick up that particular call from the industry. I commend the amendment to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horne Mr R.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say how pleasant it is to follow the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), a sincere and genuine speaker who, while he may disagree with us, always removes any personal references from his speech and just gets involved with doing his job, and he is well respected because of that.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I must try and do the same. I do not believe that the government could possibly consider supporting the amendment, for a number of reasons. The point has been made by speakers on the other side that the drought is not a new thing. Drought has been in Australia now, in some parts of it, for up to four years. Press coverage indicates that the government is going to make an announcement this afternoon, and also there is a fair exposure of what the statement is going to say. And what we find is that, after four years of drought in some areas, the representatives, as they claim, of country people get up and move an amendment like this a matter of hours before the government makes a major statement on the drought relief package that it is going to offer—and they expect us to take it seriously.

That, of course, is not putting down the drought or its effect. I would simply remind members opposite to have a look at the record of the state government in New South Wales and see how much it underspent its budget last year on rural assistance funding, and then see what it did to that component of its budget this year. They will find that not only did it underspend it last year by some $9 million, it immediately cut its budget this year by a similar amount, using the argument, `It was not spent last year so we do not need it this year.' That is the sort of thing that is happening on the other side of politics.

Having said that, let me get on with some of the important issues, some of the positive aspects of this legislation that is before us today. There are two parts of it that relate specifically to my electorate. One is the wine industry bill and the other one is the chicken industry bill.

Before we get on to those specifics, I had the good fortune, during the parliamentary recess in winter, to visit Japan, Korea and Taiwan. One of the things that we noticed there was that, because those countries are demanding high quality food imports, Australia is indeed one of the most highly regarded sources for fresh, clean food. That is the way it has to stay. That is why we must ensure that we are going to continue putting money into research and development to ensure that the quality of our produce is number one.

In my electorate, the chicken industry employs in the order of 2,000 people. The Steggles processing plant is just outside my electorate. It employs in excess of 500 people. There are many growers and supporting industries inside my electorate. Their major concern at present is the problem of imported chicken meat. Of course, the only way we are going to prevent imported chicken meat from coming into Australia is by ensuring that the standard that we have for our chicken meat is something that cannot be reproduced elsewhere, and that our consumers will not stand for less than the best that we can offer. It is also the best insurance we have to make sure that chicken exports from Australia can grow, because—as I have already mentioned—the Asian countries of Japan, Korea and Taiwan, with their imports of chicken meat, will demand only the best.

I fully support the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill, because it means that that is the best way to safeguard the future of our chicken industry, and it is an extremely valuable industry. This bill's function is to monitor and assess the levels of chemical residues in raw plant and animal commodities, to give domestic and international consumers confidence in the quality and safety of those products, and to assist in identifying the causes and possible solutions of chemical residue problems.

There is growing concern about chemical residues in food, as consumers expect a high standard of assurance about food safety and quality. I am sure that there is a great deal that we do not know about the effect of residues in foods that we eat. I am sure that at some time down the track we are going to expose some of the dangers that we have allowed ourselves to be exposed to simply because of the herbicides and the pesticides that we have used over a long period of time. I am fully supportive of that.

I will now go on to the parts of the legislation related to the wine industry. Before I do, I would like to read a few extracts from the Business Review Weekly that was published on 19 September 1994. The article is headlined `Southcorp's Europe Strategy Rewarded'. It goes on to talk about an Australian wine's winning the most prestigious award in Britain for wine. Not only does this article talk about our going ahead and winning some of the `best in class' awards; it states:

The morning after the award ceremony of one of Britain's most prestigious wine competitions, David Combe is sitting in his office in Richmond, Surrey, barely able to conceal his delight at Southcorp Wines' triumph.

Combe, Southcorp Wines' senior vice-president, international, admits he knew in advance that Penfolds Bin 707 stood a good chance of winning the International Wine Challenge's bordeaux-style category. But even he was surprised when it also won the competition's most coveted trophy, for the best red wine overall.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to talk about some of the wines that won their classes. There was a Henschke red, a Rosemount from the Hunter Valley, of course, a cabernet shiraz, and a Penfolds cabernet sauvignon that was tailor-made for the British market. He says:
These awards demonstrate in absolute terms that by any criteria our quality is exceptional. It's not just a price-quality relationship.

That is the level that our wine industry has got to internationally, and that is why we have to ensure that this government does all it can to enable the wine industry to stay at that level. I would remind everyone that last year the world wine industry produced some three million litres of wine more than was consumed. Obviously, the big problem our wine industry faces is that, in a world where there is overproduction of wine, to get a place in a market there will be cost cutting. Again, our wine is being bought because it is the best.

PARA.TAB: I believe that these two pieces of legislation are going to enhance that reputation. Firstly, there is the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill. The purpose of this bill is to revise the arrangements for levies paid under the Wine Grapes Levy Act and to ensure that money will be spent on research and development for the wine grape industry. Sure, it will increase the maximum levy for research and development to $3 per tonne for grapes. But, if that extra dollar per tonne enhances our reputation as a premier winemaker, I think everyone in the industry and everyone outside the industry would agree that it is money well spent.

The other section of the bill is about the method of collection and who the levy is collected from. No-one denies the fact that all wine grape growers effectively pay their levy now. If they do not crush their own grapes, they pay the fee to the organisation that is crushing their grapes for them, but they still pay it. Of course, it denies the small grape grower the right to participate in the decision making process of the wine industry, and to deny some of our boutique wine makers that right is a denial of natural justice, it is a denial of participating in the process of democracy. I support this change too because those small grape growers do understand, probably more than anyone else, the value of producing a wine for a niche market. They know how it is done. They simply do not have the capital or do not have the land to produce a large quantity of grapes and therefore support the capitalisation so that they have their own crushing, fermentation and bottling process. They should be allowed to participate in the decision making process of the wine industry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that many other people wish to speak on this legislation, and none more important than my very good friend and colleague the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who represents that magnificent seat on the north coast and does it very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should also mention the member for Richmond (Mr Newell), who does a good job too; there is no doubt about that. We share some time on a committee together and I really enjoy his company too. I support the bills.

—I want to set the record straight with regard to drought, because I believe that there have been quite a number of incomplete and ignorant statements made this morning about drought, particularly severe drought, from which we are now suffering in Queensland and northern New South Wales. When the coalition government lost office in 1983—and that was after the 1982 drought, which in itself was a severe drought—the rural adjustment scheme was being provided with more money in real terms than it is now, and that was being made available to more people at the lower end of the financial spectrum in farming than what is now the case. There was no assets test on unemployment benefits or, if you like, jobstart and newstart. There was no assets test on Austudy, because it was recognised then, and still is by the coalition, that if the average value of a farm property or, for that matter, many unincorporated town businesses, is about $750,000, then people are effectively ruled out of any assistance by an assets test, even if they cannot sell the property—and that is the case now.

PARA.TAB: Farm household support was there, and it was brought in by the coalition government in 1977, because even without an assets test, unemployment benefits did not provide a similar type of safety net for the self-employed sector of this country, as has always been the case for the salary and wage sector of this country. Drought was in the natural disaster scheme and IEDs, income equalisation deposits, were there, with a good incentive in their form to encourage people to put aside money in good years against bad years. That is very important for those areas where fodder is not an alternative, either because the farmers are grain growers or because they are low rainfall areas.

In 1982 there was a very severe drought. I will explain more about the difference between severe drought and ordinary drought in a minute. The fodder subsidy was brought in at that time. It was brought in to preserve the national herd and flock, which it did very successfully. It saved Australia billions of dollars in exports by maintaining wheat production or, if you like, grain production, wool production and meat production. In this one year, we are now looking at a loss of about $2 billion in exports because of the drought. If much of the sheep flock is killed or dies—and remember that once sheep are shorn in many parts of Australia, they will be shot, because there is not the money to continue to feed them—there will be a dramatic loss in income for this nation.

I acknowledge that there was some rorting of that fodder system. There is in every government system, but in the variety of reviews of that system that took place afterwards, I could quite clearly say that I have more evidence in my office each year of rorting of other government programs in my electorate, whether they be social security, jobs training, Aboriginal schemes, ethnic schemes, or whatever. It happens with all those schemes. We have to take that into context when we consider whether there should be a program or not. The fact that a program is not going to be administered perfectly is not a conclusive argument against it.

The Labor government came in in 1983 and changed just about everything that was in place to meet the next severe drought. Income equalisation deposits were virtually ruined, and three attempts by the Labor government to bring them back have not been successful. I think, in particular, of an announcement by the Labor government in one budget to improve the equalisation deposit scheme, but it was deferred for 12 months, so that woolgrowers who were then receiving a high price for their wool were prevented from investing in those deposits. For members of the government to criticise farmers for not putting aside money in good years for bad years, when they themselves have ruined what was in place to assist and encourage farmers to do so, is really very hypocritical, if not disgraceful.

We are looking again at the assets test at the moment. That was brought in by the government. It has fiddled with changes since, recognising that what it has done has been ideological and unfair. It is still not a realistic recognition of the capital formation needed by a non-incorporated business, farm or non-farm, to provide any sort of reasonable equity in welfare compared with the rest of our society. The fact is the member for Maranoa said that there are only 392 recipients of household support at this time when we have got parts of Queensland in their fourth year of drought and our wool growers are at one of their worst points ever.

Concerning natural disasters and drought, a loaded committee was set up by this government some years ago to remove drought from the natural disaster relief scheme. There was a minority report, supported by the NFF representative, that severe drought should remain in the natural disaster arrangements. Remember: when we have natural disaster arrangements, there are agreements with the states on the range of measures which both the Commonwealth and the states are prepared to support. They could be on transport; they could be on fodder; they could be on water. They should recognise—and the policies we have had in place do recognise—that some forms of assistance are not as sensible with regard to environmental degradation as others. For example, it may be more sensible to provide a transport subsidy to get stock out rather than to bring fodder in. One has to be flexible with this.

One thing the Labor government has forgotten about altogether with regard to drought and natural disasters is that, under the natural disaster arrangements, not just farmers but town business people in those affected areas can receive assistance—up to $100,000 a year at four per cent interest. Therefore, the Labor government has, by its action, removed the main form of assistance for small businesses in towns affected by drought. The government has also fiddled around with investment allowances—sometimes in and sometimes out. It has therefore reduced the incentive and the ability for farmers in the higher rainfall areas, where it is sensible for them to have fodder, to have the necessary equipment. Once again, it is a disgrace that this government can accuse farmers of not preparing for drought when it has taken those things away.

As for the next accusation, that somehow or other we have just come up with a drought policy, that is also wrong. I was the shadow minister for agriculture or primary industry for both the 1990 and 1993 elections. In both those election policies we had drought provisions and they are still policy. Those policies were supported by the NFF and are, to my knowledge, still supported by the NFF.

I now want to make a point about where we have moved with drought policy over the years since 1982. I am taking into account that committee which recognised the difference between severe drought and ordinary drought and recognised that there is an ability for farmers—or there should be an ability for farmers if they are given reasonable incentives—to cope with the dry year that happens every three to four years. I accept that is a natural part of farming. It should be able to be covered, provided there are reasonable incentive arrangements such as IEDs, et cetera. But look at our severe droughts—the droughts that occur every 10 to 15 years. I am talking here about southern Australia and the exact years may not relate to northern Australia. The years are 1944, 1957, 1967, 1982 and 1994. There is this recurring pattern of severe drought. It is impossible for anyone completely to cover themselves, particularly when they have had domestic cost price pressures and USA and EC export subsidies reducing prices abroad and there have been no IEDs in place to assist.

When we are talking about drought, we are talking about two types of drought: the severe drought which has been in place for up to the fourth or fifth year in parts of southern Queensland, the Darling Downs and parts of northern New South Wales; as distinct from the failure of the winter rainfall in the winter rainfall areas of southern Australia as the drought moves further south. We should recognise a far greater need for those people who are now into their fourth year of drought.

It is interesting that the states are providing a range of drought assistance measures at the present time, even though the natural disaster arrangements will not come in to assist them. Some of those measures include fodder subsidies, whether for transport or for fodder itself. There has been no criticism by this government of that action, and there has been no criticism by farmer organisations of that action. Yet, somehow or other, there is suddenly criticism of this addition by the coalition of a fodder subsidy to its current drought policy.

Our drought policy is very clear. It has been in place, as I said, for some years. It is there in our election policy, and it remains policy. First of all, we return to worthwhile incentive based income equalisation deposit arrangements, which will give incentives to farmers to put money aside in better years. We have always recognised that, even when we move from no assets test whatsoever to assets tests, in cases of agriculture and the self-employed generally, there are situations where the assets test should not apply.

Our policy clearly states that, in severe situations such as wool price downturns, droughts, floods, et cetera—and whether it be for Austudy, for household support, for jobstart, or whatever—the assets test prevents food being put on the tables of people who, in some cases, are in their fourth year of drought and prevents children receiving adequate education. It really is a disgrace that there is a need in this country for well-meaning people—whom I commend—to send food parcels to the people so affected. It is a disgrace that they should have to do so because there is no safety net there—which there should be for every Australian in this day and age.

At long last, the government is waking up; but it has taken it years to do so. The most educationally disadvantaged group in this country at the present time is the children on farm properties in those drought affected areas which are not close to a regional community where there is the necessary education so that they can attend every day. I hope that the government does keep catching up, because it has got a long way to go.

The government also changed the rural adjustment scheme so that it no longer covers the lower end of at risk farmers. The scheme basically now is almost a second bank, and that is not what the rural adjustment scheme was put in place to be. There is a need to bring back investment incentives so that people can cover ordinary drought better. It is important that we have the essential elements of policy in place. If they are not in place, it is too late when they are finally brought in. There is no better evidence that it is too late now than that we are into the fourth year of drought in the Darling Downs and yet it is only now that something is going to be done, as I understand it, about the assets test.

The only changes and additions that the coalition has made—and they were announced by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson)—to drought policy recently were, firstly, better recognition of farm workers, who of course are also hurt in times of drought, and, secondly, in times of severe drought, a fodder subsidy. A fodder subsidy is a very sensible thing to propose, because of the question of its impact on the future earning capacity of this country. In particular, we are looking at two very big industries being at risk. The first is wool: there are going to be millions of sheep shot, or dying once they are shorn, unless rain comes—because farmers cannot afford to keep feeding them. The second is the beef feedlot industry, which has been remarkably successful. In big dollar terms, it is probably the most successful value adding industry in Australia in the way it has improved. Perhaps the dairy industry might match it. It is certainly ahead of the wine industry at this stage, but it is at risk in the Japanese and other markets, because of the price of grain.

There is no point in talking about the price of grain going up if we had a subsidy scheme; the price of grain has doubled now. There is, however, an outer parameter to the price of grain, which is the import parity price of grain. That would still apply if there were a scheme in place. The import parity price is approximately $220 a tonne. It is perhaps possible to land it for about $180 or $190, but then there is the question of transport, and there are also some problems with quarantine with certain situations.

The initial reaction of the National Farmers Federation was only to the fodder subsidy; it did not react to all of other elements of the policy that the honourable member for Gwydir announced. It forgot that the real question of price for grain in a drought is the import parity price of grain because there is basically no fodder or hay left in Australia now and there will not be any with the failure of the winter rainfall areas in the south. It forgot that it had already supported the other elements.

Now that the federation has read the policy—and it has admitted that it had not read the policy—there is pressure from its own state organisations, and from commodity groups, which are all telling the Canberra section of the National Farmers Federation what they think of that initial reaction.

I return to what is a terrible situation in this country. We are one of the most affluent countries in the world but good meaning people have had to prepare food parcels to be sent to help other people in this country because this government removed the safety net that would have allowed them to put groceries on the table.

If this drought continues—and I hope it does not continue—this government is going to be forced to adopt more and more the policy that we have had in place for years, whether it likes it or not. Today's announcement will certainly be incorporating some of that.

Finally, I want to refer to one of the other bills, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill. Grapes, together with other forms of irrigated horticulture, provide one of the major seasonal labour sources in this country. My area has more deciduous fruit and tomatoes than grapes but the Sunraysia area has grapes for both dried vine fruit and wine. There are about 15,000 to 20,000 people employed for about three months early in the calendar year, of which about 10,000 come in from other areas. It is a unique and genuine job creation situation each year. It is very valuable with regard to exports, import replacement and value adding. Particularly for the young people—the more physically fit people—it is valuable work experience and it takes them away from that mentality of unemployment benefit or jobstart.

Unfortunately—and I genuinely say unfortunately—the government's policy, as announced in its white paper, concentrates on the long-term unemployed and this will actually work against finding jobs or placing young people in jobs in irrigated areas where there is a very large seasonal demand.

Each year, the Commonwealth Employment Service in the Shepparton and the Goulburn Valley area in my electorate goes on a tour of about a dozen CES offices in New South Wales and Victoria. These CES officers, together with fruit grower representatives who pay their own way, explain to the CES people in those other places the type of labour that is required and when it will be required. They advise them to stay in touch because weather can change the time the fruit is picked. My office traditionally has stayed open over that early New Year period because of problems with people coming in. That money will not be available any more.

We are only talking about a few thousand dollars as against the hundreds of millions of dollars for these other schemes which do not provide the genuine jobs that this scheme provides. I ask the government to look again at this unintended consequence of its policy. This is a sensible arrangement whereby industry and the Commonwealth Employment Service work together to find people for those many thousands of jobs. These jobs give people the valuable experience of genuine jobs and the arrangement benefits both sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say from the outset that the federal Labor government has an enormous amount of concern for the problems in the bush. There is a recognition of the severe drought, and of the crisis situation facing many people out there, especially in Queensland and northern New South Wales and, of course, in the other areas that are also being affected at this time. I also recognise the genuine feeling that many of the speakers on the other side have for those areas. They have local connections there, and they know the sort of situation that people are in, as do members on our side. We have put considerable amounts of money into drought relief recently, and this afternoon, or later this evening, we will be announcing a package—
—When do you think that will be?

—After cabinet this afternoon, we will be announcing a package. I would hope that it is a significant and substantial package, and that it is targeted and well constructed. I believe that it will be, and I think it will go a long way to addressing some of the very real problems in country Australia at the present time.

PARA.TAB: However, I will deal now with the amendment moved by the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). I see that as merely a means for members of the opposition to be able to talk about drought, and I suppose that is fair enough. But if they are fair dinkum and if they want to push that, let them take it down to the other house and let us have a debate down there, by which time our package will be out. I put that challenge to the member for Maranoa and others: cut out the rubbish that you are carrying on with and say to us, `We will put this to a vote in the other house', because to me, that is simply a means of your being about to do a bit of squawking up here—particularly the member for Maranoa. I noted that in his speech he spent a lot of time talking about the chicken industry, and he certainly had a long squawk after that, but on the drought issues he sounded a bit like a dead chook.

The issue really is about policy and we have heard a number of references to policy. The member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), interjecting on the member for Richmond (Mr Newell), said, `Oh, we have had that policy for a long time.' Our problem over this side is that we really do not know what your policy is. We have had Fightback, we have had the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) changing policy on the run, and actually saying that he is not going to release any details of any policy, so you can understand our confusion about where you stand on a lot of areas. Nonetheless, it is good to have you standing up and saying that this is your policy on drought. But we are confused, absolutely confused, about your position on a lot of issues. It seems to me that the opposition, to a great extent, has not got that rigorous approach to policy that enables it to bring out that sort of defined policy that is well constructed and targeted.

It has been said by many recently, particularly in the press, that a good opposition is necessary, and I think that nowhere more than in policy issues is that essential. I have got to say that I am confused about where you stand on a whole range of issues. I would like to know—and that is a genuine comment—where the opposition stands on a whole range of issues .

The member for Maranoa also attacked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for visiting drought stricken areas. He said it was late. I think the real problem that members opposite see there is that the visit was so welcomed, and it was. It is not drawing a long bow at all to say that the Newspoll polling in the Australian, which was taken in the days directly after that visit to outback Australia, showed such a marked swing towards the Prime Minister. I think that he is very well accepted in the bush, and the policy statements he makes are well constructed. He showed genuine concern, as we all do on this side, and I am confident that, with the Prime Minister's support, we are going to have a good package for country Australia.

But, bearing in mind that you attack him for visiting the bush, I think there is a real fear of him being out there. If we look at the most recent Bulletin poll, for instance, we see that he is the preferred Prime Minister in rural Australia. That puts a real scare into some of the people opposite. They do not like to see him out in rural Australia, and they doubletalk it around and say, `He should have been here sooner' or `He should come more often', but the reality is that members opposite do not like him being there.

I suppose that is understandable, because the National Party mostly does not like him being there. I also get that feeling up my way or when I go to other areas, but we will keep coming. The Prime Minister will keep doing the trips and we will keep bringing out good, rigorous, well-constructed policy for country Australia. I note many of the comments coming from the people who met the Prime Minister on his recent tour, and members opposite also will see that country Australia is already recognising the value of having a government that can put together good policy.

We will be opposing this amendment for obvious reasons. The challenge to people opposite, if they want to carry the matter further, is that we will have a debate. By then we will know what our package is and we will be able to tell you all about it.

There is another challenge, though, contained in this issue of the Prime Minister's visits to drought areas in Australia and to country Australia generally. Why do not members opposite get Mr Downer to visit some of their electorates? He is an embarrassment, an absolute joke, throughout the breadth and width of Australia. I challenge the honourable member for Maranoa to get Mr Downer to his electorate. Mr Kerin's comment about Mr Downer is very apt: that his greatest ability is changing which foot he has in his mouth whilst still keeping the silver spoon there.

Today we are discussing the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill and the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill. These bills are being debated together and I believe that there is little likelihood of opposition to them, even given the amendment that the honourable member for Maranoa has proposed.

Part 1 of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is primarily procedural. The amendments have become necessary because of changes to the structure of the former ministerial councils dealing with agriculture, water resources, soil conservation and rural adjustment issues. These duties are now performed by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand and the terminology in the legislation needs to be amended to accommodate these changes.

The amendments will affect the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council Act 1984, the Biological Control Act 1984, Rural Industries Research Act (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1985, the Rural Industries Research Act 1985, the Pig Industry Act 1986, the Horticultural Policy Council Act 1987, the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989 and the Primary Industries Council Act 1991.

The bill also proposes to give all producers who pay the wine grapes levy an entitlement to vote at the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation's annual general meeting. This will occur through changes to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980. Amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 will ensure more consistent terminology in the Wine Grapes Levy Act 1987, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980. It will clarify those people who are entitled to speak and vote at the annual general meeting of the wine industry.

In the general outline of the bill, part 4 deals with ensuring that ecologically sustainable development procedures are considered in the research and development activities of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. Given the widespread environmental degradation of some of the marginal wool producing areas, this is an important amendment which will help arrest the slide in the environmental amenity of these areas.

The second part of part 4 allows for greater flexibility in the use of funds received from patents or trademarks associated with non-research and development activities for activities other than research and development.

Amendments to the Farm Household Support Act are most timely. As honourable members would realise, the farm household support scheme offers support measures to farmers who are experiencing financial difficulties—as many are now because of drought. The scheme provides assistance in meeting the day-to-day living expenses of farmers who are unable to access further commercial finance. Farm household support is a loan which is available for up to two years at commercial interest rates and is paid at the jobsearch allowance rate. The payment is made fortnightly by the Department of Social Security, which administers the scheme on behalf of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The main eligibility criterion for the scheme is the inability to access further commercial finance. Evidence for this is a certificate provided by the commercial finance institution to the Department of Social Security and indicating that the farmer is unable to access further commercial loans. Once that inability to obtain finance is established, Social Security will apply an income and assets test. The assets test excludes farm assets, which are broadly defined as any assets essential to the running of the farm. Life insurance and superannuation held by the farmer are also excluded.

There are two groups of farmers who benefit from the scheme. There are those who believe they have a future in the industry but are unable to obtain further commercial financial support, and there are also those who have decided to leave farming but require support while they arrange the sale of the property. The first group can receive finance to meet the family's daily living expenses whilst remaining on the property and working to put the business back onto a firm footing. There are no repayments required until the family comes off the scheme, with scope to repay over five or 10 years. Farmers in the second group who sell their property within nine months will receive a payment equivalent to the balance of the farm household support they would have received had they remained on the land for the full nine-months grant period. These are worthwhile initiatives, but I have heard a number of complaints about the scheme's administration, so I welcome amendments made to allow for immediate delivery.

The bill also contains measures to amend the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 to allow fishing permit holders greater flexibility in nominating which boat is to be used with that permit. Although few of the hundreds of fishermen in my area fish in Commonwealth territorial waters, I know that replacing vessels is often stifled by red tape and that fishermen would welcome any moves to reduce the bureaucratic difficulties involved. Arrangements to enable funds collected from the cattle industry to be used for target testing programs and for education extension programs to be aimed at reducing contamination on farms will result from amendments to the National Residue Survey Act 1992, while proposed amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act are aimed at eradicating an anomaly in funding arrangements for the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation.

The bill also amends the definition of the sugar industry organisations in section 4(1) of the Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987. This amendment has become necessary because of the consolidation of sugar industry organisations. The new organisations have been prescribed for the purposes of the definition. A small drafting error in the Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Act 1993, on which I had the pleasure of speaking earlier, has required a slight amendment. Similarly, the wording of the Wool Tax Act (No. 3) 1964 has now become redundant, since wool dealers are now required to be registered, which fact means that the term `registered wool dealer' is anachronistic.

This bill further amends the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 to extend the definition of grain. This is to allow seed testing and certification of a greater range of seed species. Improvements in the allocation of levy payments to equity holders in the wheat industry fund will result from minor changes to the Wheat Marketing Act.

I would like to also talk about the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994. The bill is intended to allow for an increase from the present 0.02c a head to 0.06c a head on the levy rate payable for the national residue survey. The move is aimed at increasing consumer protection and further ensuring that Australia's meat chicken producers retain their clean and green image, domestically and internationally. It is also in line with the government's clean food export strategy; and that strategy is another example of policies which are there to develop commercial linkages.

The strategy is designed to enhance Australia's image as a supplier of clean, fresh, quality produce in overseas markets. It is based on creating a market advantage for Australian fresh and processed food on the basis of its quality and origin from a clean environment. The program is a joint initiative with industry and government funding and is conditional upon matching industry funds.

The Commonwealth is working with industry to ensure that the clean food export strategy has the backing of necessary quality assurance programs, and the amendments to the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chicken) Amendment Bill 1994 will allow for increases in the charges for inspection through changes to the regulations rather than legislation. I would not expect the rate to increase markedly over either the short or medium term. Since 1991 the value of chicken exports from Australia has more than doubled, making the protection of our `clean supplier' tag an important ingredient in continuing growth in this export performance.

The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 affects the components of the wine grapes levy. Producers of small quantities of grapes will now pay a flat fee as the marketing component of the levy. This is not unreasonable if these producers are gaining commercially from the generic promotion of wines elsewhere. They will also gain the right to attend, debate and vote at annual meetings of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation.

There is also consideration of amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994. These amendments follow the amendments to the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill in that they change the definition of a producer to include those who produce less than 10 tonnes of wine grapes. They also make the definition of a producer clearer in terms of who is the owner of the wine. Under current legislation a grape producer can have his or her grapes turned into wine by a processor and then returned to him or her for sale. The legislation deems that the processor is the owner of the wine, when clearly that is not so. The amendment will address this anomaly.

As I said at the outset, I believe this is an appropriate way to deal with non-contentious legislation. We have had ample opportunity to examine the contents of the bills and to raise any concerns we may have about them. I commend the bills to the House.

Finally, I would like to say something about some of the comments made previously about communities coming together to support those in drought areas. We have heard the opposition attack the farmhand appeal, and we have heard the opposition attack the measures being taken by communities to help those in need in rural Australia. In my own electorate last weekend the community got together and loaded seven full semitrailers of hay to go to western areas. There was help there from the army to do that, with army trucks. Last night there was a concert in Grafton to raise money for rural areas. I think that is admirable. I think it is a wonderful exhibition of the community coming together and helping their fellow Australians, and I have got nothing but praise for all those people involved. I certainly commend the Grafton, Lower Clarence and north coast people who have been involved with that, including the Rotary clubs that organised it.

The government is playing its part in the farmhand appeal, matching that dollar for dollar. Later this evening there will be an announcement of the drought package of extra assistance. That recognises that this is no ordinary drought, that in many areas it has been going on for quite a number of years and that the present policies, whilst having the right direction, perhaps have settings that cannot handle the present severe, extreme and long-lasting drought. Those people out in the areas of rural Australia that are affected by drought can rest confident that the federal Labor government will do everything in its power to bring in well constructed, targeted policies that will assist them through this very difficult period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak here in Obscurityville, if you like, the second chamber. In fact, it took me some time to figure out how to get the second chamber on my television set. We are talking about the plight of Australian farmers here—

PARA.TAB: Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), is an expert on television sets. I do not get the opportunity to watch television much; I am too busy working to become an expert in that field, so I will let him tell me how to change the channels.

PARA.TAB: In the other chamber we are talking about whether or not university students pay $100. It is really earth-shattering stuff that is going on in the House, really important stuff. I cannot help but comment upon the fact that I served on university councils to which I was elected on a number of occasions. I remember a debate of 2 1/2 hours on one occasion as to whether we should pay 4c or 2c deposit on soft drink bottles. On another occasion we debated for three days the issue of one vote, one value. The relevant motion had been moved by a chap who was elected as a vice-president by 200 votes when there were some 1,000 electors putting somebody else up. So I reflect upon the relative importance placed upon the farmers in this country in view of the stupidity and frivolous legislation being passed in the House. It gives a clear indication of the thinking of the federal government with respect to farmers.

Let me put the matter into perspective for the few of us who are here listening, although I note that we do circulate some of our speeches so there will be a large number of people at least reading what I have to say. One of my very best friends has left his station property to go working as a clerk, leaving his wife at home so that he can hold on to the station property. His brother has gone to work as a plant operator so his family are by themselves. Where we had property until recently, my neighbour, a very fine young man, worked for six months navvying in the railway, away from home, with his wife and three kids left by themselves, 200 kilometres to the nearest town. Not surprisingly, that very successful marriage collapsed as a result of the brutality forced upon him by the systems that exist in Australia. I will have more words to say about that further down the track. My good friend told me that his neighbour is away selling Amway. That is how he is holding on to his station.

When you go into the station homesteads these days, it is amazing because there is nothing on the walls. There is not a print or even a picture on the walls; there are not even any family photographs in frames anywhere. It is depressing beyond belief. The last time I visited a station I sat on a wooden stool because there was literally no furniture in the house. I am not saying that five or maybe seven per cent of people out there are not doing reasonably well and not living in these sort of conditions but there is a very large proportion—and I am saying 20 per cent—that are living in homes without anything on the walls whatsoever—

TALK.START.PARA: —Poverty.

—An absolutely grinding poverty. In the state of Queensland since the socialist government won the election, if you worked as a railway worker in Julia Creek or you had a small holding outside Julia Creek, seventh, eighth and up to ninth grade schooling was available for your children in Julia Creek. That school has been closed, so if you want a secondary education beyond seventh grade, you have to send your kids away to a boarding school. The cost of the very reasonable and very excellent boarding schools in Charters Towers, which educate most of our children in north Queensland in this situation, is about $8,000 to $9,000. The maximum amount of government assistance, it appears to me, and I am informed, that people can get is about $5,000. There is no way that people who have an average income of minus $24,000 are going to be able to put $8,000 away to enable their children to get an education.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the very few advanced countries in the world where a large sector of the population now has no secondary education available to it. We are not talking about tertiary education. We are not talking about whether we pay an extra $200 a year for student fees, as with the frivolity in the other place; we are talking about basic secondary education. I do not know how many doors are left open—very few, I suspect—in our society today to people who have only a seventh grade education.

I will shortly come to why grinding poverty and oppression has been imposed by this government. It has not been something that is the result of the natural interplay of market forces or of natural conditions such as drought.

Where we had a little piece of land, I think there were 10 of us, but there are now only two station owners left—possibly three—and one of those stations is on the market. I suspect another one will go on the market shortly. They have been sold up by the banks. When these people leave the stations, it is not like losing a job, because they still have some sort of income. It is not a very good income but they leave with an income called unemployment benefits. When a station owner is booted off his station he takes with him maybe $50,000 or $100,000 or $200,000 in debt. So he takes bankruptcy, which is pretty damn unpleasant, or wears that debt for the rest of his days.

I might add that some of the people in that situation—particularly the sheep farmers now that sheep prices are coming back—are being pushed out a window and taking the tax debt with them. Even if they take bankruptcy, they must still pay off the tax debt. That is the degree of oppression and human misery that is occurring.

In the last two years in the tiny area which was my old state electorate we have had five suicides. One of them had been the local president and, if my memory serves me correctly, an ex state president of the Cattlemens Union. He had the unenviable task of shooting 100 of his little steers which he did not have the money to keep alive. He shot them to at least enable his cows to survive. In even reasonably ordinary times he would have been able to buy fodder or at least supplementary feed that would have enabled the cows and the calves to survive. In this case, probably half the cows will be lost.

The banks were also bearing down upon him, I would imagine. In the depths of his human misery, after four generations of hard work and sacrifice and after watching every single thing that was built by that hard work and sacrifice being lost to him, and knowing that he could not pass on the same advantages that he had enjoyed to his children, he took the ultimate and terrible solution.

He was only one of five. A combination of stresses imposed by the regime of oppression that has come down on these people as they lose their jobs and feel the hopelessness of never being able to get a job was the cause, in my opinion, of those five suicides. Those are the suicides that I know of. I am not in a position to know of all the suicides that occur in that area any more.

I have not bothered to talk very much in party circles or even in public about these drought relief measures because they are so frivolous and ridiculous. The farmers are going to get nine months of social welfare benefit and that is only if they leave. So what we are actually doing is forcing people to leave the land. That is the solution of this government.

It is with deep pain and regret that I say that I do not understand how any of the farmers in Australia have a body representing them called the NFF. I do not understand how its director last year said that one in three farmers had to go. As Julian McGauran, a senator I am very proud of in the National Party, said: `Who are you? Are you the PR officer for the banks? You are the spokesman for the liquidators, are you?' The NFF director has not recanted or apologised. That was the position he took, and then the same people had the temerity to attack proposals being put up by us—and I thought they would have applauded any assistance. I will bet London to a brick that they applaud the proposals that come forward this afternoon.

One has to ask questions about these people. If they take money to do a job and sell out the people that they are supposed to be doing the job for—and I would add to this the actions of the NFF on the issue of Mabo—all I can say is that there is a name to describe them, which I am not going to use. Other people who are listening and are conscious of what we are saying here today can put that name on people who take someone's money and then sell them out.

Let me now turn from the emotional side of this—I do not think we can understand it unless we can see the emotional side of it—to the hard statistical evidence that is out there. There have been four reports, and each of them has been a very fine, professionally prepared report. One report was done by the Queensland Farmers Federation. Another report was commissioned by the ABC and other people at Longreach. I pay very great tribute to them. A report was done by the UGA. John Wilson was the author of that report and he is an excellent person. A very brilliant report was done by Peter Newman of the DPI Arid Research Centre at Longreach.

Those reports all confirm, reconfirm and reinforce in one's mind the situation—I am specifically referring to Peter Newman's report—that more than half of the farmers of inland Queensland owe in excess of $500,000. Their projected income for the forthcoming year is minus $24,000. We are now talking about providing them with unemployment benefits for nine months, if they will run away with their tails between their legs.

Many of these people came to the most barren land on earth. The first three exploration parties to the north were wiped out to a man. Kennedy's party was wiped out with only one survivor, Jackey Jackey. Burke and Wills were wiped out—there were no survivors out of those who had continued into Northern Australia—and Leichhardt's party vanished without a trace. They were the first three attempts by Europeans to venture into this land, and yet the farmers of inland Queensland have turned the land into some of the most productive parts of the planet. That is what these people have achieved.

I never cease to have immense pride in reflecting upon the fact that if I had driven across my old electorate from Cloncurry to Hughenden 100 years ago, I would not have seen a single goanna, or kangaroo, or emu, or anything. There were no human beings; nothing. The land was completely barren because there was no surface water. Today there are an estimated two million kangaroos in that area. There are people in the area who are producing maybe $300 million a year in export earnings for this country. The thanks that these people are getting from their country is in the form of handouts—toothbrushes and food parcels. Heaven only knows that what the people in the cities are doing is a wonderful thing; but how humiliating, how degrading!

Have a look at a race of people who have been reduced to mendicants. Go to the Todd River in Alice Springs and have a look at what handing out taxpayers' money does to an individual and what it has done to five individuals whom I knew in my electorate. They were all people whom I knew well, but they are now dead. They chose to shoot themselves rather than to continue in the pain and misery in which they worked.

Who is to blame for this? When I buried my father, I gave a lot of thought to what I would say. People probably give more intense thought to what they will say at their father's funeral than they would give to many other things in their life. Many wonderful things have happened for people in Queensland—for example, the coal that has been mined, the dams that have been built and the artesian bores. The most important thing that happened to the people who live in inland Australia was the minimum price scheme for wool. For the first time in our history we could have some sort of security.

We looked with hungry eyes at the sugar industry. I am pleased that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) is here because he will back me up in saying what a wonderful industry the people within that industry achieved with their statutory marketing. They built the most magnificent and secure industry of probably any that we have in Australia. When the wool industry got statutory marketing in a very mild form, for the first time in our history we went through two decades of stable reasonable prices.

According to Senator Ron Boswell, in a very brilliant speech in the Senate, the week before Mr Kerin's infamous press conference—and I do not blame him, he was forced to do it by the former Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—we were selling 80 per cent of our wool and we were selling it at 890c a kilo. The week after Mr Kerin's press conference, we were selling arguably only 20 per cent, most certainly not more than 30 per cent of the wool clip, and we were selling it at the minimum price of 870c a kilo. Of course, the government ultimately abolished the wool marketing scheme. All right, people can ride the laissez-faire capitalist system; they can ride the roller-coaster; but they can just hope and pray that when the price is down they do not get hit with a drought. It is goodbye time for them if they do. We can ride the droughts. Give us a reasonably stable price and we will ride the droughts. We have weathered 100 droughts in the last 100 years—20 or 30 huge droughts, anyway, in that period of time. We can do that.

At times we can even weather interest rates of 10 and 15 per cent—a regime that does not exist anywhere else in the world for farmers. But we cannot stand up to a regime of 25 per cent. In fact, I do not need anyone to tell me what farmers are paying in interest rates. In our last year on St Francis station we paid, with bank charges, 29 per cent interest rates. Even at 25 per cent, debt is doubling every 3 1/2 years. When we went into our seventh year of debt, for people who had started with a mild debt of $100,000, that doubled and doubled again. Then they are up to the half million dollar mark, which is exactly the figure quoted in all of those things—and I think that $100,000 in debt would have been a fairly average figure.

How could anyone impose a regime of 25 per cent interest rates and expect businessmen of any ilk to be standing upright? Our bankruptcies roared away from 4,500 a year when the ALP government was elected to 16,000 a year by 1990-91. Now for every bankruptcy that occurs there are maybe 10 or 20 people who go broke. In fact, I only know one person who has taken technical bankruptcy, but I know hundreds, maybe even thousands if I were pressed, who have gone broke and lost everything. They have lost more than everything; they have walked away with a huge debt on their shoulders. For the rest of their lives they will have to try to pay off a debt of $100,000 or something of that nature. What the government can and should be doing is what every government in Australian history has done. The government can borrow money. The bond rate is six or seven per cent. It can borrow money at six or seven per cent. Please, why can it not borrow that money at six or seven per cent and parcel it out to the farmers at six or seven per cent?

There were special help banks. There was the Commonwealth Development Bank which has been commercialised and abolished as a special help bank; there was the Agricultural Bank in Queensland which has been abolished as a special help bank; there was the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, PIBA, which was established as a special help bank, which has been commercialised. There is no special assistance available this time. For the first time in Australian history—in this century, anyway, as far as people's memories can go back—the farmers have had to face a situation where there is no special help bank out there. They just had to wear the 25 per cent interest rates or fall over dead.

The government has said, `We have been generous to you, we have given you $100 million.' What absolute rubbish! It has not given $100 million to the farmers. That money goes to the banks—that is where the money is going—because the banks are borrowing at five and six per cent and are loaning that money out at 10, 11 and 11 1/2 per cent. That is what is happening. And that money is going to pay the ridiculous margin. No banking group anywhere else in the world is enjoying the margins enjoyed by the Australian banks at present.

The answers are out there at the present moment. Heaven only knows that if we had some sort of formula by which write-offs could occur then the banks would be very reasonable in many cases in allowing those write-offs to occur. During the Great Depression, the farming sector was not in as much trouble as it is now. Interestingly, there were only two years in which the farming sector was worse off than it is now—in terms of both the number of people in trouble and commodity prices. At the end of those two years, the banks sold the debt for 30 per cent discounts. The answers are there. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wonder whether I might make a contribution on this particularly important legislation that is before the Main Committee and, after a short address, seek to have this debate adjourned.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important issue. The bills before us are the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill and the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chicken) Amendment Bill. I want particularly to address the chamber at the moment about the ravages of drought in Queensland and New South Wales, bearing in mind that the weather pattern is moving further south.

My colleague the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who spoke before me, is no doubt going through the pain and suffering with his Queensland constituents. I know the pain and suffering that is occurring in his area, and also in other parts of Queensland and in New South Wales, where people have been in the grip of drought for many years. I also heard the contribution made this morning by my colleague the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), indicating the spread of the drought further and further south into the grain growing areas and the grazing areas, right down through his electorate and also into my electorate, which it abuts in north-central Victoria.

During the last week I took the opportunity to go through some of my rural areas—areas like St Arnaud, the shire of Kara Kara, Newbridge and Logan, which are right on the brink. The weather pattern is moving further south every day and it now extends right down to the Great Dividing Range in Victoria. I have never seen areas like Kyneton and Redesdale, Elphinstone and Harcourt in such a state. These are areas that normally at this time of the year are very green and lush, and at the moment there is absolutely no growth there. As I say, the ravages of the drought are moving further and further south.

There is one thing that I want to put to the parliamentary secretary who is present, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay). I do thank him for listening to the debate, because there are a number of issues that require, I believe, bipartisan support on drought relief. It is not only the impact of drought at the present moment that requires attention but also the provision of drought proofing of properties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The member for Kennedy acknowledges that there should be support for the rural community on an ongoing basis and on a permanent basis to take precautions and undertake drought proofing. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has (a) his Department or (b) Standards Australia been informed of a revised, positive attitude of the Australian Fire Authorities Council to the standardisation of standpipes and couplings following the NSW bushfires in January 1994 during which some interstate brigades were unable to share equipment because of the lack of universal coupling.
(2) Was a Standards Australia project on standard connections for firefighting equipment which commenced in May 1990 subsequently halted; if so, will it recommence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Fire Authorities Council has not yet confirmed its willingness to support the development of the standardisation of standpipes and couplings to either my department or to Standards Australia.

(2) Standards Australia raised a project on standard connections for firefighting equipment in May 1990 with the intention of establishing a single system throughout Australia. Standards Australia has indicated to my Department that it does not have the in-house expertise to develop a standard on standpipes and couplings and is reliant on input from committee members. Consequently, if the committee members do not support the project, little headway can be made. Standards Australia would be willing to reopen the project if the major user, the Australian Fire Authorities Council indicated their willingness not only to develop such a coupling, but to implement phased transfer of all equipment such that the standard coupling could be utilised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: Are children over the age of 12 who have paid a full adult air fare and departure tax at the full adult rate entitled to half the adult allowance of duty free goods; if so (a) why and (b) will the Minister review the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the Honourable Member's question:

PARA.TAB: The concessional treatment of goods accompanying travellers arriving in Australia is governed by the terms of Customs by-laws made under the Customs Tariff Act. The provisions of these by-laws allow for the concessional entry of goods to the value of $400 when imported by an adult, ie a person 18 years of age or over. Persons under the age of 18 years are regarded as children and are legally entitled to half this concession, except for alcohol and tobacco, for which no allowance is provided.

These provisions relating to passenger concessions have been in place since 1987, following an inquiry by the former Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). The IAC endorsed the long standing practice of granting children half the adult passenger concessions (with the exception of alcohol and tobacco).

Customs convened a meeting of relevant government departments on 14 September 1994 to discuss a potential review of the passenger concession system. The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator the Hon Chris Schacht has requested that the level of concessions for children be considered during the planned review.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: Since the answer to question No. 281 (Hansard, 27 September 1993, page 1172), what progress has been made in reconsidering the reservations lodged by Australia in acceding to or ratifying UN Human Rights instruments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Racial vilification legislation is currently under Government consideration. The Attorney-General, in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, will review the terms of Australia's reservations to Article 20 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and Article 4(a) of the Convention on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination (CERD) once that process is complete.

The Prime Minister has announced proposed changes to the Sex Discrimination Act which will, among other matters, open a large number of combat-related positions in the Australian Defence Force to women. Once those amendments to the Act are made, the Attorney-General, in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, will review the terms of Australia's reservations to the Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) and Article III of the Convention on the Political Rights of Women.

In the context of Accord Mark VII negotiations, on 1 June 1994 the Prime Minister announced that in preparing next year's Budget the Government will give consideration to introducing a maternity allowance paid through the social security system. Once the details of the allowance are finalised, the Attorney-General, in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, will review the terms of Australia's reservation to Article 11(2) of the Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW).
